The day I finally said "yes" to marrying his ruthless rival, the man who'd ditched me three times at city hall crumbled‚Äîbegging on his knees while I glowed in the arms of the enemy he'd always despised.
I'd waited eight hours outside city hall that day, clutching useless queue tickets, my heart cracking a little more with every passing minute. Aaron Galloway‚Äîthe man who'd promised me forever‚Äîwas supposed to show up to get our marriage license. But he never did. For the third time, he'd chosen her. His fragile, depressed "old flame" Patti, the one he could never say no to.
I wasn't going to cry anymore. I wasn't going to beg. So I pulled out my phone and dialed the number I'd ignored twice before: Fredrick Pollard, Aaron's biggest business rival and the man who'd proposed to me every single time Aaron stood me up.
"I agree to marry you," I said, voice steady for the first time in years.
Fredrick didn't gloat. He just said he'd be back from his trip in a week and if I still meant it, we'd meet at city hall. No pressure. No games. Just a chance.
That week, I erased Aaron from my life. I boxed up every photo, every couple's mug, every memory we'd built in the apartment he'd connected to mine. I called a real estate agent and listed it for sale‚Äîprice didn't matter, I just wanted it gone. Wanted every trace of him gone.
Of course, Aaron came home that night with Patti clinging to his arm like a damsel in distress. He didn't even apologize for ditching me. He just announced she was staying with us because her "depression flared up." Then he ordered me to prepare the guest room for her.
I watched him give Patti his own bedroom while he crawled into mine hours later, wrapping his arms around me like nothing had happened. "Sorry I flaked," he murmured against my neck. "Patti needed me. Let's postpone the license until she's better. Be patient, okay? I'll make it up to you."
Patient. I'd been patient for years while he ran to her every time she cried wolf.

‚ÄúTell Sara to wake her up for breakfast,‚Äù Edgar said with a scoff.
‚ÄúShe‚Äôs not getting into Shoneport University anyway.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs been up since six,‚Äù the maid replied.
‚ÄúJust got back from her morning run.‚Äù

The family turned‚Äîand saw Briar standing in the doorway.
Calm. Cold. Unbothered.
‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry,‚Äù she said, eyes gleaming.
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt eat with trash. It ruins my appetite.‚Äù
Then she walked upstairs like they didn‚Äôt exist.
-------
Chapter 1 Like Mother, Like Daughter
It was September in Dasmieca. In the fancy Jennings family mansion in Shoneport, five people sat in the living room, the tension thick enough to choke on.

Briar Jennings, fresh off a flight from abroad, kicked back on a couch, legs crossed like she owned the place. The other four were crammed together on the other couch across from her, clearly uncomfortable.

Gunfire from a phone game kept blasting from Briar's phone, cutting through her father's voice every time he tried to speak.

"Briar, you just got back. You don't even know the first thing about running a company," Edgar Jennings said. "Why don't you hand your shares over to me? You'll still get your annual cut just like before."

Briar didn't even glance up. Her thumbs kept tapping.

Edgar continued, "Your brother's grown now. It's time he started learning the ropes. I could transfer him half your shares so that he doesn't have to start from scratch."

There was still nothing from Briar.

"And about that engagement to the Hargreaves boy," Edgar added. "You've been gone for years. You don't even know him anymore. Why not let your sister take your place?"

No matter what he said, Briar just kept playing, like he wasn't even there.

Edgar's patience wore thin. His face darkened, but before he could explode, Halle Jennings‚Äîhis ever-graceful wife and longtime expert at playing the good stepmother‚Äîgently placed a hand on his chest.

"Edgar, she just got home," she said sweetly. "Let her settle in first."

Chapter 1 Like Mother, Like Daughter
It was September in Dasmieca. In the fancy Jennings family mansion in Shoneport, five people sat in the living room, the tension thick enough to choke on.

Briar Jennings, fresh off a flight from abroad, kicked back on a couch, legs crossed like she owned the place. The other four were crammed together on the other couch across from her, clearly uncomfortable.

Gunfire from a phone game kept blasting from Briar's phone, cutting through her father's voice every time he tried to speak.

"Briar, you just got back. You don't even know the first thing about running a company," Edgar Jennings said. "Why don't you hand your shares over to me? You'll still get your annual cut just like before."

Briar didn't even glance up. Her thumbs kept tapping.

Edgar continued, "Your brother's grown now. It's time he started learning the ropes. I could transfer him half your shares so that he doesn't have to start from scratch."

There was still nothing from Briar.

"And about that engagement to the Hargreaves boy," Edgar added. "You've been gone for years. You don't even know him anymore. Why not let your sister take your place?"

No matter what he said, Briar just kept playing, like he wasn't even there.

Edgar's patience wore thin. His face darkened, but before he could explode, Halle Jennings‚Äîhis ever-graceful wife and longtime expert at playing the good stepmother‚Äîgently placed a hand on his chest.

"Edgar, she just got home," she said sweetly. "Let her settle in first."

But her eyes weren't so sweet. They flicked coldl | ‚ÄúTell Sara to wake her up for breakfast,‚Äù Edgar said with a scoff.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs been up since six,‚Äù the maid replied.
‚ÄúJust got back from her morning run.‚Äù

The family turned‚Äîand saw Briar standing in the doorway.
Calm. Cold. Unbothered.
‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry,‚Äù she said, eyes gleaming.
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt eat with trash. It ruins my appetite.‚Äù
Then she walked upstairs like they didn‚Äôt exist.

Whitney Moore sent a message with a smile: [Honey, I just landed. See you at City Hall in half an hour.]

Today was the day she and Carter Harris were finally getting their marriage licenses.

From their college romance to their engagement, and now, getting their marriage licenses, it had been exactly five years.

Whitney leaned back in the seat, the morning sunlight casting a warm glow on her radiant face, giving her an extra touch of gentleness.

The driver caught her smile in the rearview mirror and joked, "Wow, you just landed, and you're already rushing straight to City Hall?"

"Yeah, Valentine's Day. You know, I made the appointment two weeks ago," Whitney replied with a smile.

The driver chuckled. "Young folks really know how to make things special. My daughter couldn't snag a spot for today, so she's getting hers tomorrow instead."

"Congrats," Whitney said.

"Same to you," the driver replied.

But even after Whitney got out of the cab, she still hadn't heard back from Carter.

Pouting, she dialed his number.

The phone rang for ages before he finally picked up.

Carter's voice was flat, giving nothing away. "Yeah? What's up?"

Whitney's grip tightened on her phone as she asked, "Carter, where are you? I'm already at City Hall. We will‚Äî"

Carter cut her off. "Whit, I can't come right now."

She swallowed hard. "What happened? Didn't we agree to get our marriage license today?"

"Yeah, something came up. Let's just do it another day, okay? Any day works. It's not a big deal," Carter said.

Yet to Whitney, it was a big deal. She had made the appointment two weeks ago and had been expecting this very day ever since.

A girl's voice rang out. "Carter, are you on the phone? Everyone's waiting downstairs for us to join them for breakfast."

Whitney's heart dropped. That was Emily's voice.

Emily Miller was the girl whom the Harris family adopted eighteen years ago. Whitney wondered, 'Is Emily back to the country?'

The day I finally said "yes" to marrying his ruthless rival, the man who'd ditched me three times at city hall crumbled‚Äîbegging on his knees while I glowed in the arms of the enemy he'd always despised.
I'd waited eight hours outside city hall that day, clutching useless queue tickets, my heart cracking a little more with every passing minute. Aaron Galloway‚Äîthe man who'd promised me forever‚Äîwas supposed to show up to get our marriage license. But he never did. For the third time, he'd chosen her. His fragile, depressed "old flame" Patti, the one he could never say no to.
I wasn't going to cry anymore. I wasn't going to beg. So I pulled out my phone and dialed the number I'd ignored twice before: Fredrick Pollard, Aaron's biggest business rival and the man who'd proposed to me every single time Aaron stood me up.
"I agree to marry you," I said, voice steady for the first time in years.
Fredrick didn't gloat. He just said he'd be back from his trip in a week and if I still meant it, we'd meet at city hall. No pressure. No games. Just a chance.
That week, I erased Aaron from my life. I boxed up every photo, every couple's mug, every memory we'd built in the apartment he'd connected to mine. I called a real estate agent and listed it for sale‚Äîprice didn't matter, I just wanted it gone. Wanted every trace of him gone.
Of course, Aaron came home that night with Patti clinging to his arm like a damsel in distress. He didn't even apologize for ditching me. He just announced she was staying with us because her "depression flared up." Then he ordered me to prepare the guest room for her.
I watched him give Patti his own bedroom while he crawled into mine hours later, wrapping his arms around me like nothing had happened. "Sorry I flaked," he murmured against my neck. "Patti needed me. Let's postpone the license until she's better. Be patient, okay? I'll make it up to you."
Patient. I'd been patient for years while he ran to her every time she cried wolf.

The day I finally said "yes" to marrying his ruthless rival, the man who'd ditched me three times at city hall crumbled‚Äîbegging on his knees while I glowed in the arms of the enemy he'd always despised.
I'd waited eight hours outside city hall that day, clutching useless queue tickets, my heart cracking a little more with every passing minute. Aaron Galloway‚Äîthe man who'd promised me forever‚Äîwas supposed to show up to get our marriage license. But he never did. For the third time, he'd chosen her. His fragile, depressed "old flame" Patti, the one he could never say no to.
I wasn't going to cry anymore. I wasn't going to beg. So I pulled out my phone and dialed the number I'd ignored twice before: Fredrick Pollard, Aaron's biggest business rival and the man who'd proposed to me every single time Aaron stood me up.
"I agree to marry you," I said, voice steady for the first time in years.
Fredrick didn't gloat. He just said he'd be back from his trip in a week and if I still meant it, we'd meet at city hall. No pressure. No games. Just a chance.
That week, I erased Aaron from my life. I boxed up every photo, every couple's mug, every memory we'd built in the apartment he'd connected to mine. I called a real estate agent and listed it for sale‚Äîprice didn't matter, I just wanted it gone. Wanted every trace of him gone.
Of course, Aaron came home that night with Patti clinging to his arm like a damsel in distress. He didn't even apologize for ditching me. He just announced she was staying with us because her "depression flared up." Then he ordered me to prepare the guest room for her.
I watched him give Patti his own bedroom while he crawled into mine hours later, wrapping his arms around me like nothing had happened. "Sorry I flaked," he murmured against my neck. "Patti needed me. Let's postpone the license until she's better. Be patient, okay? I'll make it up to you."
Patient. I'd been patient for years while he ran to her every time she cried wolf.

The next morning, Pa | Chapter 1: The Wolfless Omega
Addison 
As I approached the main gates of Blackbolt High, a highschool meant for werewolves, I could already pick up several conversations all around me. It wasn't the first time I had heard most of the chatter, but on that morning, there seemed to be more enthusiasm and I wondered why. Even as I looked around, everyone seemed so hyped.
With my sense of hearing so powerful, it was difficult to focus on a particular conversation.
As soon as I stepped through the front doors, the sound of chatter and lockers slamming was much louder. 
With my head low, I made my way down the crowded hallway so I could get to my locker. I didn't bother to look up as I was certain all I would see would be the mockery on people's faces, just because I was a wolfless Omega, or at least, that was what everyone believed. However, they were absolutely wrong about me.
It had already been two years since I had transferred to Blackbolt High after moving to a small town called R

The day I finally said "yes" to marrying his ruthless rival, the man who'd ditched me three times at city hall crumbled‚Äîbegging on his knees while I glowed in the arms of the enemy he'd always despised.
I'd waited eight hours outside city hall that day, clutching useless queue tickets, my heart cracking a little more with every passing minute. Aaron Galloway‚Äîthe man who'd promised me forever‚Äîwas supposed to show up to get our marriage license. But he never did. For the third time, he'd chosen her. His fragile, depressed "old flame" Patti, the one he could never say no to.
I wasn't going to cry anymore. I wasn't going to beg. So I pulled out my phone and dialed the number I'd ignored twice before: Fredrick Pollard, Aaron's biggest business rival and the man who'd proposed to me every single time Aaron stood me up.
"I agree to marry you," I said, voice steady for the first time in years.
Fredrick didn't gloat. He just said he'd be back from his trip in a week and if I still meant it, we'd meet at city hall. No pressure. No games. Just a chance.
That week, I erased Aaron from my life. I boxed up every photo, every couple's mug, every memory we'd built in the apartment he'd connected to mine. I called a real estate agent and listed it for sale‚Äîprice didn't matter, I just wanted it gone. Wanted every trace of him gone.
Of course, Aaron came home that night with Patti clinging to his arm like a damsel in distress. He didn't even apologize for ditching me. He just announced she was staying with us because her "depression flared up." Then he ordered me to prepare the guest room for her.
I watched him give Patti his own bedroom while he crawled into mine hours later, wrapping his arms around me like nothing had happened. "Sorry I flaked," he murmured against my neck. "Patti needed me. Let's postpone the license until she's better. Be patient, okay? I'll make it up to you."
Patient. I'd been patient for years while he ran to her every time she cried wolf.

In the firewood shed.

A girl, around fifteen or sixteen, curled up tightly, her body shaking uncontrollably as if trapped in a horrifying nightmare.

Her pale pink jacket was filthy beyond recognition.

The butterfly hairpin had long fallen off, and her tangled hair was covered in mud.

After struggling in the pile of firewood for a while, she suddenly jolted awake with a hoarse scream, "It wasn't me! I swear it wasn't me!"

Her voice trailed off, and as she took in her surroundings, the terror in her eyes gradually gave way to confusion.

Hadn't she died?

Her eldest brother Joshua Wallen had cut out her tongue, her second brother Avery Wallen poisoned her, her fifth brother Andrew had severed her legs, her fourth brother Clyde had kicked her out, and she had taken a sword for Tessa.

In the end, her third brother Russell had tossed her body into the cold pond‚Ä¶

Why was she back in the firewood shed in the Chancellor's estate?

In her previous life, she had been locked up here for a full month, leaving her with severe rheumatism that tormented her for three long years.

She hadn't expected to be reborn.

As reality hit her, Margaery Wallen's pale face twisted into a bitter smile.

She was the daughter of the Chancellor's estate. Her mother had died during a difficult childbirth, and the midwife told her father Raul Wallen that only she had survived.

Being a preemie, weak and frail, and her mother's last memory, she became the family's prized possession.

Raul often said, "Margaery, from now on, you have me and your five brothers to back you up. I wasn't going to cry anymore. I wasn't going to beg. So I pulled out my phone and dialed the number I'd ignored twice before: Fredrick Pollard, Aaron's biggest business rival and the man who'd proposed to me every single time Aaron stood me up.

Patient. I'd been patient for years while he ran to her every time she cried wolf.

Not long ago, I was chatting with an advisor named David.

Great guy. Ton of years in the game. Solid book of business. Clients love him.

But he was stuck.

Same AUM. Same revenue. Same ceiling he'd been smacking his head against for years.

And look... it's not like he wasn't trying.

He'd spent money on marketing before. Agencies. Ads. The whole thing.

Problem was... all that money went into THEIR pockets. Not his brand. Not his business.

Just... poof. Gone.

Here's the thing...

David wasn't bad at his job. Dude was actually brilliant at it.

His problem? He didn't have a client acquisition SYSTEM. A funnel that worked for HIM, building HIS brand, attracting HIS ideal clients.

So we built him one.

Not a cookie-cutter template. A custom funnel designed around his expertise, his market, his ideal client.

And here's what's different about how we work:

Every dollar he spends on ads? Builds HIS brand. Not ours. He keeps the asset.

And we only make money on the upside we add.

Read that again.

We're not an agency that charges whether it works or not. We're a performance partner. We only win when YOU win.

Fast forward 6 months.

$5M+ in net new AUM.

Not from cold calling. Not from begging for referrals. From a funnel that brings qualified prospects to him on autopilot.

Wild, right?

We've done this with 28+ advisors now. Helped firms anywhere between $30M to $1.2B in managed assets.

Or, hey... you could keep paying agencies that charge you whether you get clients or not.

You know - throwing money into the void, hoping something sticks, watching your "brand" get built on rented land.

If it floats ya boat.

Anyhoo. I put together a short video breaking down exactly how this works.

No fluff. No 47-minute webinar. Just the system.

Watch. Click. Then scale. üöÄ

üëâ Link below.

P.S. Only take on 3 new advisors per month. First come, first served.

Patient. I'd been patient for years while he ran to her every time she cried wolf.

Whitney Moore sent a message with a smile: [Honey, I just landed. See you at City Hall in half an hour.]

Today was the day she and Carter Harris were finally getting their marriage licenses.

From their college romance to their engagement, and now, getting their marriage licenses, it had been exactly five years.

Whitney leaned back in the seat, the morning sunlight casting a warm glow on her radiant face, giving her an extra touch of gentleness.

The driver caught her smile in the rearview mirror and joked, "Wow, you just landed, and you're already rushing straight to City Hall?"

"Yeah, Valentine's Day. You know, I made the appointment two weeks ago," Whitney replied with a smile.

The driver chuckled. "Young folks really know how to make things special. My daughter couldn't snag a spot for today, so she's getting hers tomorrow instead."

"Congrats," Whitney said.

"Same to you," the driver replied.

But even after Whitney got out of the cab, she still hadn't heard back from Carter.

Pouting, she dialed his number.

The phone rang for ages before he finally picked up.

Carter's voice was flat, giving nothing away. "Yeah? What's up?"

Whitney's grip tightened on her phone as she asked, "Carter, where are you? I'm already at City Hall. We will‚Äî"

Carter cut her off. "Whit, I can't come right now."

She swallowed hard. "What happened? Didn't we agree to get our marriage license today?"

"Yeah, something came up. Let's just do it another day, okay? Any day works. It's not a big deal," Carter said.

Yet to Whitney, it was a big deal. She had made the appointment two weeks ago and had been expecting this very day ever since.

A girl's voice rang out. "Carter, are you on the phone? Everyone's waiting downstairs for us to join them for breakfast."

Whitney's heart dropped. That was Emily's voice.

Emily Miller was the girl whom the Harris family adopted eighteen years ago. Whitney wondered, 'Is Emily back to the country?'

Now, undercover as a wealthy heir, Aaron is forced into marriage...with Dawson himself. Their masks fall off after the wedding. Aaron keeps pretending to love him. Dawson acts vengeful‚Äîbut spoils him instead. When Dawson "dies" in a crisis, Aaron breaks down and confesses. When I was grieving over my miscarriage, some girl, nine months pregnant claimed that her kid belonged to my loved biker.
"I was looking for Shadow. He has the right to know about the child's existence..." 
Shadow joined the military when he was eighteen, and I had barely seen him since then.
He said no one else had ever been on his bike. I couldn't believe he betrayed me.
"If you continued to make false claims that he would get a DNA test done and then file charges against you." My voice cracked. 
"I haven't lied about anything!" 
I just needed some time. I knew that he would be pissed at me for leaving him. 
But at the time, I thought that it was the right thing to do.
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

Tulip
My name is Tulip Ivy Sterling, and I am 23 years old. My life has been one big trial of ups and downs. And I have to say, there have been more downs than ups. Especially over the last few years. And it has been so hard. Harder than what I had thought that my life would be after I turned eighteen.
Before I turned eighteen, I was used to having a hard life. When I was first born, I had a loving family. I had a mom and two dads, and three brothers. And we were all one big happy family, or so I thought. When I was ten, something happened to cause my parents to split up. I never did find out what happened to cause it.
All I knew was that the boys and I had to go and have DNA tests done to find out which of us belonged to my dad, Sean. Unfortunately for me, I was the only one that the test showed belonged to him. So, I had to spend every weekend at his house with him. And most of my breaks from school were spent at his house. I hated it.
He was always very abusive to me, and it was mentally and emotionally most of the time. When he only had me on the weekends, he would stick to mentally and emotionally abusing me. But when I had to spend a longer amount of time with him, it would get physical. He would beat me and lock me in a closet for hours at a time, sometimes for days.

When I was grieving over my miscarriage, some girl, nine months pregnant claimed that her kid belonged to my loved biker.
"I was looking for Shadow. He has the right to know about the child's existence..." 
Shadow joined the military when he was eighteen, and I had barely seen him since then.
He said no one else had ever been on his bike. I couldn't believe he betrayed me.
"If you continued to make false claims that he would get a DNA test done and then file charges against you." My voice cracked. 
"I haven't lied about anything!" 
I just needed some time. I knew that he would be pissed at me for leaving him. 
But at the time, I thought that it was the right thing to do.
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

Tulip
My name is Tulip Ivy Sterling, and I am 23 years old. My life has been one big trial of ups and downs. And I have to say, there have been more downs than ups. Especially over the last few years. And it has been so hard. Harder than what I had thought that my life would be after I turned eighteen.
Before I turned eighteen, I was used to having a hard life. When I was first born, I had a loving family. I had a mom and two dads, and three brothers. And we were all one big happy family, or so I thought. When I was ten, something happened to cause my parents to split up. I never did find out what happened to cause it.
All I knew was that the boys and I had to go and have DNA tests done to find out which of us belonged to my dad, Sean. Unfortunately for me, I was the only one that the test showed belonged to him. So, I had to spend every weekend at his house with him. And most of my breaks from school were spent at his house. I hated it.
He was always very abusive to me, and it was mentally and emotionally most of the time. When he only had me on the weekends, he would stick to mentally and emotionally abusing me. But when I had to spend a longer amount of time with him, it would get physical. He would beat me and lock me in a closet for hours at a time, sometimes for days.
Once I turned e | When I was grieving over my miscarriage, some girl, nine months pregnant claimed that her kid belonged to my loved biker.
"I was looking for Shadow. He has the right to know about the child's existence..." 
Shadow joined the military when he was eighteen, and I had barely seen him since then.
He said no one else had ever been on his bike. I couldn't believe he betrayed me.
"If you continued to make false claims that he would get a DNA test done and then file charges against you." My voice cracked. 
"I haven't lied about anything!" 
I just needed some time. I knew that he would be pissed at me for leaving him. 
But at the time, I thought that it was the right thing to do.
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

For 37 years, dermatologists have been prescribing Minoxidil for Black women over 50. The FDA never tested or approved it for black women. I'm one of those dermatologists, and I'm done staying quiet.

My name is Dr. Vanessa Doucet.

I'm a board-certified dermatologist with 32 years of clinical experience, published research in the Journal of Dermatological Science, and I've treated more than 1,200 Black women suffering from chronic hair loss and thinning hairlines.

And for three decades, I prescribed Minoxidil for edge loss.

Every single week.

To women who came into my office with see-through temples, disappearing hairlines, and edges that had been gone for months or years.

I wrote the prescription with complete confidence.

Because Minoxidil is FDA-approved.

Because it's the gold standard.

Because that's what medical school taught me to do.

But here's what I never told those women, because I didn't know it myself until four years ago.

The FDA never approved Minoxidil to reverse edge loss.

Not in Black women.

Not for traction alopecia.

Not for chemical damage.

Not for the inflammation-driven follicle miniaturization that causes 87% of chronic edge loss cases in women over 50.

The FDA approved Minoxidil in 1988 for one thing and one thing only.

To slow the progression of hereditary hair loss.

Not to reverse it.

Not to regrow what's already gone.

Not to reactivate miniaturized follicles at the temples and edges.

To slow it down.

And for 37 years, dermatologists like me have been prescribing it off-label for edge loss anyway.

Knowing the FDA approval doesn't cover what you actually need.

Knowing the clinical trials never tested it on Black women with traction alopecia.

Knowing it was designed to maintain existing hair, not bring back what you've already lost.

I know what you're thinking right now.

"If this is true, why didn't my dermatologist tell me?"

Because most of us never read the actual FDA approval documents.

We were taught in medical s | Dermatologist breaks 32-year silence about Black women's hair loss.

Three years of a perfect marriage, only to end on an operating table as a commodity.

I woke up chained to a hospital bed, discovered my billionaire husband had sold me to a black-market organ harvester, watched the surgeon prep his scalpel‚Äîand then I heard my husband laughing on the phone in the hallway, telling his mistress he'd finally found a way to get rid of me without paying a dime in divorce settlements.

The surgical lamp burned white above me.

I couldn't move‚Äîmy wrists and ankles were strapped down with leather restraints that bit into my skin every time I struggled.

"Don't waste your energy." The surgeon didn't even look at me. He was arranging his tools on a metal tray. Scalpels. Clamps. A bone saw. "Your husband paid extra for us to keep you conscious. Said he wanted you to feel everything."

My throat was so dry I could barely speak.

"There must be some mistake. My husband is Dominic Ashford. He's‚Äî"

"One of the richest men in the country. Yes, I know." The surgeon finally met my eyes, and there was nothing human in his gaze. "That's why your organs are worth so much. Clean living. Private doctors. No drugs, no alcohol. You're practically a medical-grade specimen."

I heard Dominic's voice getting closer.

"Yes, baby, I'll be home for dinner. The procedure should only take a few hours."

He appeared in the doorway, phone pressed to his ear, looking at me the way someone looks at a piece of furniture they're about to throw away.

We'd been married for three years.

Three years of me believing I was living a fairytale‚Äîthe ordinary girl who caught the eye of the untouchable billionaire.

Now I understood.

I was never the princess in this story.

I was the sacrifice.

"Dominic," I whispered. "Please. Whatever I did wrong, I can fix it. Just tell me what I did."

He ended his call and walked toward me, adjusting his cufflinks like he was heading to a business meeting instead of my execution.

"You didn't do anything wrong, sweetheart. That's the problem | I was about to hide the gift I'd prepared for our fifth anniversary in the wall of his armory when I accidentally opened a hidden safe I never knew existed.
Inside, there were no documents or gold bars‚Äîjust a bullet necklace engraved with hotel room numbers, and a diary filled with my husband's obsession for another woman.
I was still holding the custom gun I'd made for him, the grips inlaid with our initials and our date. The metal was ice-cold, but just minutes ago when I'd held it, my palms had been sweating, my heart fluttering with an almost childish anticipation.
I'd imagined his expression when he discovered this gift‚Äîperhaps a hint of genuine surprise, perhaps he'd embrace me and say "thank you."
I'd spent three whole months designing this gun.
My stomach clenched violently, like I'd been punched.
Adrian Black, my husband, the youngest godfather of a mafia family. I'd cleaned up his battlefields for five years, while he used my loyalty to pave the way for his true love.
My fingers traced the cold bullets, each one engraved with clear lettering.
"Crystal Hotel, Penthouse Suite." "Royal Garden Hotel, Room 1204." My gaze stopped on the last one, and my breathing stopped completely. "Peninsula Hotel, Sky Suite‚ÄîNight Before Proposal."
Night before proposal. That night, he'd come home very late, smelling of unfamiliar perfume.
He said it was business. I believed him. I'd even prepared hangover soup for him.
I grabbed the leather-bound diary and flipped through it quickly.
Adrian's handwriting was sharp, filled with romantic words I'd never heard, but they weren't meant for me‚Äîthey were for Olivia.
"Keira handled the dock situation perfectly today. Clean and efficient. Olivia said now she can focus on preparing for next week's art exhibition without worrying about that dirty business tarnishing her reputation. My Olivia, she only needs to live in the sunlight. Keira is the perfect shield."

My name is Tulip Ivy Sterling, and I am 23 years old. My life has been one big trial of ups and downs. And I have to say, there have been more downs than ups. Especially over the last few years. And it has been so hard. Harder than what I had thought that my life would be after I turned eighteen.
Before I turned eighteen, I was used to having a hard life. When I was first born, I had a loving family. I had a mom and two dads, and three brothers. And we were all one big happy family, or so I thought. When I was ten, something happened to cause my parents to split up. I never did find out what happened to cause it.
All I knew was that the boys and I had to go and have DNA tests done to find out which of us belonged to my dad, Sean. Unfortunately for me, I was the only one that the test showed belonged to him. So, I had to spend every weekend at his house with him. And most of my breaks from school were spent at his house. I hated it.
He was always very abusive to me, and it was mentally and emotionally most of the time. When he only had me on the weekends, he would stick to mentally and emotionally abusing me. But when I had to spend a longer amount of time with him, it would get physical. He would beat me and lock me in a closet for hours at a time, sometimes for days.
Once I turned e | When I was grieving over my miscarriage, some girl, nine months pregnant claimed that her kid belonged to my loved biker.
"I was looking for Shadow. He has the right to know about the child's existence..." 
Shadow joined the military when he was eighteen, and I had barely seen him since then.
He said no one else had ever been on his bike. I couldn't believe he betrayed me.
"If you continued to make false claims that he would get a DNA test done and then file charges against you." My voice cracked. 
"I haven't lied about anything!" 
I just needed some time. I knew that he would be pissed at me for leaving him. 
But at the time, I thought that it was the right thing to do.

After the charity gala, I caught my husband cheating on me with his VP of Marketing.
A low, intimate laugh came from Derek's locked office.

I approached, bracing myself for something unknown.
"Charlie doesn't understand me the way you do."
I heard Derek's gentle, intimate voice when I was only three feet from the door.
Then it was her.
Vivian Clarke. 
His VP of Marketing.
Wearing the dress I'd complimented hours earlier‚Äîsitting on his desk, his hand on her waist, intimately.
I didn't gasp. Instead, I stood there for a full three seconds, with a shock-stricken calm, meticulously recording every detail.
The way her fingers were twirling in his hair. The lipstick mark on his collar.The champagne gla-sses on his desk two of them, half-empty, celebratory.
Then I closed the door. Carefully, silently. So quietly that they didn't even notice.
He's a hero in their eyes. A visionary. A godda-mn saint.
And I'm the idiot who believed him.
This perfect life is a lie, and I‚Äôm done playing along.

No, not tired. Empty.

Tulip
My name is Tulip Ivy Sterling, and I am 23 years old. My life has been one big trial of ups and downs. And I have to say, there have been more downs than ups. Especially over the last few years. And it has been so hard. Harder than what I had thought that my life would be after I turned eighteen.

Was it a blessing to marry your best friend?

I was not very sure what Nathan thought. But for me, becoming his chosen mate was a dream come true. And now‚Äîwhat was even more miraculous‚Äîwe were going to have our first pup.

"Congratulations, Luna Kyra." The pack doctor told me cheerfully as she could see the shock in my eyes,"We are about to welcome the first Alpha heir to our pack."

I subconsciously touched my belly, and still couldn't believe a pup was lying there. Had I heard it right? I was pregnant? I was pregnant with a pup for Nathan! After three years as his Luna, I'm finally carrying the pup who would be my mate's heir,the future of the Nightfall Pack.

"Sylvia," I whispered to my wolf , "we're going to be mothers."

My wolf stirred within me, her presence warm and protective.

On the way out of the hospital, I couldn't wait to tell Nathan about our pup. I wondered what his reaction would be. Would he howl in happiness? Would he kiss me and all?Goddess, I could barely contain myself.

I cupped my red face as I fantasized. But the moment I felt the cold from the simple ring on my finger, my wildly beating heart calmed down. I almost forgot that Nathan wasn't the type to be keen on having pups, especially when our marriage was arranged by our family.

Our families have been friends for a long time ago.So our marriage also strengthen the alliance between the Nightfall Pack and the Raven shadow Pack.

Nathan was a complete gentleman, both as a friend and a mate. Every time we had sex, he was considerate but cautious‚Äîcautious not to claim me with his mark. No claiming bite, no permanent tie.

He said there was no need to add extra shackles when we were not ready.

This pup in a way, was out of plan.

My mind was becoming restless as I sat in my car. Would this be good news for him?

"You're spiraling," Sylvia murmured in my mind. "Stop overthinking. He's your mate. He'll be happy."

There was nothing I didn‚Äôt share with him.

Lucy, my stepmother, looked me over and smiled thinly. ‚ÄúYou look good, Bella,‚Äù she said quietly.

‚ÄúThanks mom!‚Äù I replied. ‚ÄúCan I show this to Craig?‚Äù

She shook her head. ‚ÄúNo, we follow the rules. It's a bad omen for the bride and groom to meet so close to the wedding.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease mom,‚Äù I whined. ‚ÄúI won‚Äôt show it on me. Just the dress in the box. He‚Äôll be so happy. It‚Äôs only bad to meet the day before,‚Äù I added. ‚ÄúNot three days before.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs bad,‚Äù she said firmly. ‚ÄúYou will see him at the rehearsal dinner tomorrow with everyone. And that‚Äôs it!‚Äù

I didn‚Äôt want to argue because Lucy was pretty stubborn usually. I sigh

Abandoned as a child, abused in boarding school, and a-ssaulted at thirteen‚Äîat seventeen I was forced to return to my parents‚Äô and brothers‚Äô mansion with my son.

‚ÄúMe and Teo have been looking for you for the past four years,‚Äù he said, his voice thick with emotion. 
His words hit me like a gentle shockÔºåmy brothers had been searching for me all this time.
A faint warmth spread through my chest, chasing away some of the chill of fear. 
But joy turned to agony when they learned my son was three, and realized what had happened to me at thirteen.
Alex‚Äôs fist hit the wall with a crash. Teo just shook his head, face ashen.
Guilt overwhelmed both of them, their shoulders hunched under the weight of it.
 For the first time, someone in this family seemed to grasp the horror I‚Äôd endured.
‚ÄúWe've let you down,‚Äù Teo murmured.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry,‚Äù Alex said, his gaze earnest. 
I whispered, ‚ÄúI believe you.‚Äù
For the first time in years, I felt a glimmer of something like belonging.

After the charity gala, I caught my husband cheating on me with his VP of Marketing.
A low, intimate laugh came from Derek's locked office.
I froze, an earring slipping from my finger. The sound came from his private office, the one even the cleaning staff locked.
I approached, bracing myself for something unknown.
"Charlie doesn't understand me the way you do."
I heard Derek's gentle, intimate voice when I was only three feet from the door.
Then it was her.
Vivian Clarke. 
His VP of Marketing.
Wearing the dress I'd complimented hours earlier‚Äîsitting on his desk, his hand on her waist, intimately.
I didn't gasp. Instead, I stood there for a full three seconds, with a shock-stricken calm, meticulously recording every detail.
The way her fingers were twirling in his hair. The lipstick mark on his collar.The champagne gla-sses on his desk two of them, half-empty, celebratory.
Then I closed the door. Carefully, silently. So quietly that they didn't even notice.
He's a hero in their eyes. A visionary. A godda-mn saint.
And I'm the idiot who believed him.
This perfect life is a lie, and I‚Äôm done playing along.
‚Äî‚Äî
The diamonds feel heavier coming off than they did going on.
I stand in front of the bathroom mirror, fingers working the clasp of the Cartier necklace Derrick gave me for our fifth anniversary. The woman staring back at me looks like she belongs in a magazine spread sleek updo, perfect makeup, designer gown that probably cost more than most people's monthly mortgage. But her eyes are tired. No, not tired. Empty.
I finally get the necklace undone and set it on the marble counter with a soft clink. The sound echoes in the cavernous bathroom, all gleaming fixtures and heated floors. This penthouse has everything. Everything except the one thing I actually need a husband who looks at me like I matter.

When I was grieving over my miscarriage, some girl, nine months pregnant claimed that her kid belonged to my loved biker.
"I was looking for Shadow. He has the right to know about the child's existence..." 
Shadow joined the military when he was eighteen, and I had barely seen him since then.
He said no one else had ever been on his bike. I couldn't believe he betrayed me.
"If you continued to make false claims that he would get a DNA test done and then file charges against you." My voice cracked. 
"I haven't lied about anything!" 
I just needed some time. I knew that he would be pissed at me for leaving him. 
But at the time, I thought that it was the right thing to do.
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

Tulip
My name is Tulip Ivy Sterling, and I am 23 years old. My life has been one big trial of ups and downs. And I have to say, there have been more downs than ups. Especially over the last few years. And it has been so hard. Harder than what I had thought that my life would be after I turned eighteen.
Before I turned eighteen, I was used to having a hard life. When I was first born, I had a loving family. I had a mom and two dads, and three brothers. And we were all one big happy family, or so I thought. When I was ten, something happened to cause my parents to split up. I never did find out what happened to cause it.
All I knew was that the boys and I had to go and have DNA tests done to find out which of us belonged to my dad, Sean. Unfortunately for me, I was the only one that the test showed belonged to him. So, I had to spend every weekend at his house with him. And most of my breaks from school were spent at his house. I hated it.
He was always very abusive to me, and it was mentally and emotionally most of the time. When he only had me on the weekends, he would stick to mentally and emotionally abusing me. But when I had to spend a longer amount of time with him, it would get physical. He would beat me and lock me in a closet for hours at a time, sometimes for days.

Tulip
My name is Tulip Ivy Sterling, and I am 23 years old. My life has been one big trial of ups and downs. And I have to say, there have been more downs than ups. Especially over the last few years. And it has been so hard. Harder than what I had thought that my life would be after I turned eighteen.

Abandoned as a child, abused in boarding school, and a-ssaulted at thirteen‚Äîat seventeen I was forced to return to my parents‚Äô and brothers‚Äô mansion with my son.
Alex, my brother, stepped forward, his eyes glistening with unshed tears. 
‚ÄúMe and Teo have been looking for you for the past four years,‚Äù he said, his voice thick with emotion. 
His words hit me like a gentle shockÔºåmy brothers had been searching for me all this time.
A faint warmth spread through my chest, chasing away some of the chill of fear. 
But joy turned to agony when they learned my son was three, and realized what had happened to me at thirteen.
Alex‚Äôs fist hit the wall with a crash. Teo just shook his head, face ashen.
Guilt overwhelmed both of them, their shoulders hunched under the weight of it.
 For the first time, someone in this family seemed to grasp the horror I‚Äôd endured.
‚ÄúWe've let you down,‚Äù Teo murmured.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry,‚Äù Alex said, his gaze earnest. 
I whispered, ‚ÄúI believe you.‚Äù
For the first time in years, I felt a glimmer of something like belonging.

Oh sh-it.
I sat frozen in my place. My 17-year-old but, which has seen better, and worse days was numb from not moving for a few hours so I couldn't have been sure whether someone stitched it to the uncomfortable leather seat. It would explain my lack of movement, right?
Wrong.
It was the pair of green eyes, staring down at me, completely shocked. It was my pair of eyes staring down at me in shock.
Funny, the last time I saw the eyes, they were filled with disgust and hatred. I took in his tall figure with masculine appearance in formal clothes, not a suit though, which I have honestly expected when I was told he was coming down here.
I slowly blinked at him, realising I was, in fact, not paralyzed. Good. That was the impulse I needed to clear my throat and stand up awkwardly. He was tall. Too tall. But honestly, due to my up bringing, everyone was taller than me.

A low, intimate laugh came from Derek's locked office.
I froze, an earring slipping from my finger. The sound came from his private office, the one even the cleaning staff locked.
I approached, bracing myself for something unknown.
"Charlie doesn't understand me the way you do."
I heard Derek's gentle, intimate voice when I was only three feet from the door.
Then it was her.
Vivian Clarke. 
His VP of Marketing.
Wearing the dress I'd complimented hours earlier‚Äîsitting on his desk, his hand on her waist, intimately.

The way her fingers were twirling in his hair. The lipstick mark on his collar.The champagne gla-sses on his desk two of them, half-empty, celebratory.
Then I closed the door. Carefully, silently. So quietly that they didn't even notice.
He's a hero in their eyes. A visionary. A godda-mn saint.
And I'm the idiot who believed him.
This perfect life is a lie, and I‚Äôm done playing along.

When I was grieving over my miscarriage, some girl, nine months pregnant claimed that her kid belonged to my loved biker.
"I was looking for Shadow. He has the right to know about the child's existence..."

But at the time, I thought that it was the right thing to do.

It was midnight on Boaz Street, Orsin City.

Beep beep beep‚Äî

Sirens screamed as the Royal Special Forces‚Äîelite operators‚Äîsurrounded the auction house, making it impossible to escape.

"All units, lock it down!"

"Fox has been spotted at Waylen Auction House! Her target tonight‚ÄîRothialand's 'Blood Ruby'!"

"She can't get away!"

"Seal every exit! Not a single bug gets out!"

But they were already too late.

Inside, a thick, smoky fog had knocked out everyone‚Äîguards, big shots‚Äîleaving them slumped on the floor.

Among the unconscious crowd, a woman in a sleek black velvet gown walked confidently toward the stage.

She took a gas mask from her bag, sliding it on with practiced ease.

Anyone watching the feed might've thought she was just another rich guest... until she pulled a hairpin from her hair, bent it into a lockpick, and jammed it into the lock of the safe holding the Blood Ruby.

Click. The "unhackable" lock popped open like a cheap toy.

"Sorry, folks," she said with a sly smirk, winking at the security camera. "Thanks for the party, but I'm taking this shiny rock home.

"Night-night."

Right there, with everyone watching, she snatched the Blood Ruby and pocketed it like it was no big deal.

Yup, that was her.

No one knew her past. No one knew who she worked for.

But everyone knew her name‚ÄîFox. The greatest thief in the world, slipping in and out of palaces and vaults like they were nothing.

The only agent ever given a 5S "global threat" classification.

But deep in her mind was another name: Narissa Everton.

"Little Narissa... my sweet flower..." That lullaby from her mother.

Too bad time had blurred the rest. All Narissa could remember was her mother's warm smile‚Äînothing else about where she came from.

With the Blood Ruby in her grip, Narissa was ready to ghost, same as always.

But then‚Äî

Bang!

The Wilsons found their real daughter.
Just like that, Luna Bennett was done.
Kicked out. No warning. No mercy.
Her rich "parents" didn't even blink.
Jennifer Wilson leaned against the doorframe, arms crossed. A lazy smile hung on her lips‚Äîbut her eyes were flat. Empty. Cold.
"Pack your stuff and go," she said."Quick. Don't drag it out. If you move slow, you won't even make it to your new place before dark."
Luna looked at her.
Bored. Blank. Not a word.
Didn't even care enough to argue.
Before Luna could turn away, another girl stepped out from behind Jennifer.
She looked thin. Too thin.
Sallow skin. Hollow cheeks. Like she hadn't eaten right in years. That kind of frailty made her eyes look huge‚Äîsoft, innocent, pitiful.
Her voice shook when she spoke. Tight. Fragile. Like it might snap any second.
"Mom..." she whispered, eyes red."This is because of me, right? Because I came back... big sister can't stay anymore."
Tears welled up. Hung perfectly on her lashes.
"If that's the case... maybe I should go back to the orphanage. I don't always get enough to eat there, but I'll still visit you and Dad. I swear. I won't forget you."
Jennifer's irritation vanished in a blink.
She rushed over, pulling the girl into her arms like she was made of glass.

When I was grieving over my miscarriage, some girl, nine months pregnant claimed that her kid belonged to my loved biker.
"I was looking for Shadow. He has the right to know about the child's existence..." 
Shadow joined the military when he was eighteen, and I had barely seen him since then.
He said no one else had ever been on his bike. I couldn't believe he betrayed me.
"If you continued to make false claims that he would get a DNA test done and then file charges against you." My voice cracked. 
"I haven't lied about anything!" 
I just needed some time. I knew that he would be pissed at me for leaving him. 
But at the time, I thought that it was the right thing to do.
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

Tulip
My name is Tulip Ivy Sterling, and I am 23 years old. My life has been one big trial of ups and downs. And I have to say, there have been more downs than ups. Especially over the last few years. And it has been so hard. Harder than what I had thought that my life would be after I turned eighteen.
Before I turned eighteen, I was used to having a hard life. When I was first born, I had a loving family. I had a mom and two dads, and three brothers. And we were all one big happy family, or so I thought. When I was ten, something happened to cause my parents to split up. I never did find out what happened to cause it.
All I knew was that the boys and I had to go and have DNA tests done to find out which of us belonged to my dad, Sean. Unfortunately for me, I was the only one that the test showed belonged to him. So, I had to spend every weekend at his house with him. And most of my breaks from school were spent at his house. I hated it.
He was always very abusive to me, and it was mentally and emotionally most of the time. When he only had me on the weekends, he would stick to mentally and emotionally abusing me. But when I had to spend a longer amount of time with him, it would get physical. He would beat me and lock me in a closet for hours at a time, sometimes for days.
Once I turned e | When I was grieving over my miscarriage, some girl, nine months pregnant claimed that her kid belonged to my loved biker.

My name is Tulip Ivy Sterling, and I am 23 years old. My life has been one big trial of ups and downs. And I have to say, there have been more downs than ups. Especially over the last few years. And it has been so hard. Harder than what I had thought that my life would be after I turned eighteen.

After the charity gala, I caught my husband cheating on me with his VP of Marketing.
A low, intimate laugh came from Derek's locked office.
I froze, an earring slipping from my finger. The sound came from his private office, the one even the cleaning staff locked.
I approached, bracing myself for something unknown.
"Charlie doesn't understand me the way you do."
I heard Derek's gentle, intimate voice when I was only three feet from the door.
Then it was her.
Vivian Clarke. 
His VP of Marketing.
Wearing the dress I'd complimented hours earlier‚Äîsitting on his desk, his hand on her waist, intimately.
I didn't gasp. Instead, I stood there for a full three seconds, with a shock-stricken calm, meticulously recording every detail.
The way her fingers were twirling in his hair. The lipstick mark on his collar.The champagne gla-sses on his desk two of them, half-empty, celebratory.
Then I closed the door. Carefully, silently. So quietly that they didn't even notice.
He's a hero in their eyes. A visionary. A godda-mn saint.
And I'm the idiot who believed him.
This perfect life is a lie, and I‚Äôm done playing along.
‚Äî‚Äî
The diamonds feel heavier coming off than they did going on.
I stand in front of the bathroom mirror, fingers working the clasp of the Cartier necklace Derrick gave me for our fifth anniversary. The woman staring back at me looks like she belongs in a magazine spread sleek updo, perfect makeup, designer gown that probably cost more than most people's monthly mortgage. But her eyes are tired. No, not tired. Empty.
I finally get the necklace undone and set it on the marble counter with a soft clink. The sound echoes in the cavernous bathroom, all gleaming fixtures and heated floors. This penthouse has everything. Everything except the one thing I actually need a husband who looks at me like I matter.

Every time my husband filed for divorce, he had only one condition: I took all the property, and he only wanted our daughter.
On my birthday, I flew across the ocean to surprise them‚Ä¶ and found him having dinner with his true love‚Äîmy stepsister.
My daughter looked at her and said, ‚ÄúMommy.‚Äù
That day, I finally woke up.
I drafted the divorce papers, gave up custody, and walked away from it all, building a billion-dollar empire from scratch.
But when I returned home one night with a business partner, my ex husband cornered me against the wall.
‚ÄúDivorce?‚Äù he said, eyes dark. ‚ÄúNot a chance.‚Äù

After seven years of marriage, my husband, Trevor, fell for another woman‚Äîeven our daughter wanted her as her new mom.
I scoffed at the years I‚Äôd wasted and handed him the divorce papers. Yet he dropped his usual aloofness, slamming me against the wall,
‚ÄúDivorce? Not a chance.‚Äù
***
When Celeste Rodriguez landed at the airport in Andostan, it was already past 9:00 pm.
It was her birthday. Her phone buzzed with messages from colleagues and friends‚Äîbut not a single one from her husband, Trevor Fleming.
Celeste's smile faded.
By the time she reached the villa, it was already past 10:00 pm.
Hannah Lynd, the housekeeper looked startled. "Mrs. Fleming... what a surprise."
"Where are Trevor and Jo?" Celeste asked, handing over her luggage.
"Mr. Fleming isn‚Äôt back yet. Miss Jordyn‚Äôs upstairs playing."
Celeste climbed the stairs. In her room, Jordyn sat in pajamas at her desk, completely absorbed.
"Jo?" Celeste called.
Jordyn turned, her eyes lighting up. In a happy tone, she greeted, "Mom!"
But then she quickly got back to what she was doing earlier.
Celeste walked over and hugged her tight, planting a kiss on her cheek. Yet the little one pushed her away and squirmed. "Mom, I‚Äôm busy." 
It had been two months since Celeste last saw Jordyn. She missed her so much that no amount of kisses felt enough. She wanted to talk to Jordyn.

One day, Wendy discovered that her husband Stanley was having an affair.

He had been seeing a college student.

It was Stanley's birthday. Wendy had prepared a table full of dishes early in the day. Just then, she heard a notification from his phone.

Ding!

He had left his phone at home. 

Wendy switched it on and saw a text from the college student.

[I hurt myself when I was carrying the cake. It hurts so much.]

After the charity gala, I caught my husband cheating on me with his VP of Marketing.
A low, intimate laugh came from Derek's locked office.
I froze, an earring slipping from my finger. The sound came from his private office, the one even the cleaning staff locked.
I approached, bracing myself for something unknown.
"Charlie doesn't understand me the way you do."
I heard Derek's gentle, intimate voice when I was only three feet from the door.
Then it was her.
Vivian Clarke. 
His VP of Marketing.
Wearing the dress I'd complimented hours earlier‚Äîsitting on his desk, his hand on her waist, intimately.
I didn't gasp. Instead, I stood there for a full three seconds, with a shock-stricken calm, meticulously recording every detail.
The way her fingers were twirling in his hair. The lipstick mark on his collar.The champagne gla-sses on his desk two of them, half-empty, celebratory.
Then I closed the door. Carefully, silently. So quietly that they didn't even notice.
He's a hero in their eyes. A visionary. A godda-mn saint.
And I'm the idiot who believed him.
This perfect life is a lie, and I‚Äôm done playing along.
‚Äî‚Äî
The diamonds feel heavier coming off than they did going on.
I stand in front of the bathroom mirror, fingers working the clasp of the Cartier necklace Derrick gave me for our fifth anniversary. The woman staring back at me looks like she belongs in a magazine spread sleek updo, perfect makeup, designer gown that probably cost more than most people's monthly mortgage. But her eyes are tired. No, not tired. Empty.
I finally get the necklace undone and set it on the marble counter with a soft clink. The sound echoes in the cavernous bathroom, all gleaming fixtures and heated floors. This penthouse has everything. Everything except the one thing I actually need a husband who looks at me like I matter.
Tonight was supposed to be special. The Annual Blackwood Foundation Gala, where Derrick's company donates obscene amounts of money to various charities while everyone  | Abandoned as a child, abused in boarding school, and a-ssaulted at thirteen‚Äîat seventeen I was forced to return to my parents‚Äô and brothers‚Äô mansion with my son.
Alex, my brother, stepped forward, his eyes glistening with unshed tears. 
‚ÄúMe and Teo have been looking for you for the past four years,‚Äù he said, his voice thick with emotion. 
His words hit me like a gentle shockÔºåmy brothers had been searching for me all this time.
A faint warmth spread through my chest, chasing away some of the chill of fear. 
But joy turned to agony when they learned my son was three, and realized what had happened to me at thirteen.
Alex‚Äôs fist hit the wall with a crash. Teo just shook his head, face ashen.
Guilt overwhelmed both of them, their shoulders hunched under the weight of it.
 For the first time, someone in this family seemed to grasp the horror I‚Äôd endured.
‚ÄúWe've let you down,‚Äù Teo murmured.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry,‚Äù Alex said, his gaze earnest. 
I whispered, ‚ÄúI believe you.‚Äù
For the first time in years, I felt a glimmer of something like belonging.

Oh sh-it.
I sat frozen in my place. My 17-year-old but, which has seen better, and worse days was numb from not moving for a few hours so I couldn't have been sure whether someone stitched it to the uncomfortable leather seat. It would explain my lack of movement, right?
Wrong.
It was the pair of green eyes, staring down at me, completely shocked. It was my pair of eyes staring down at me in shock.
Funny, the last time I saw the eyes, they were filled with disgust and hatred. I took in his tall figure with masculine appearance in formal clothes, not a suit though, which I have honestly expected when I was told he was coming down here.
I slowly blinked at him, realising I was, in fact, not paralyzed. Good. That was the impulse I needed to clear my throat and stand up awkwardly. He was tall. Too tall. But honestly, due to my up bringing, everyone was taller than me.

When I was grieving over my miscarriage, some girl, nine months pregnant claimed that her kid belonged to my loved biker.
"I was looking for Shadow. He has the right to know about the child's existence..." 
Shadow joined the military when he was eighteen, and I had barely seen him since then.
He said no one else had ever been on his bike. I couldn't believe he betrayed me.
"If you continued to make false claims that he would get a DNA test done and then file charges against you." My voice cracked. 
"I haven't lied about anything!" 
I just needed some time. I knew that he would be pissed at me for leaving him. 
But at the time, I thought that it was the right thing to do.
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

Tulip
My name is Tulip Ivy Sterling, and I am 23 years old. My life has been one big trial of ups and downs. And I have to say, there have been more downs than ups. Especially over the last few years. And it has been so hard. Harder than what I had thought that my life would be after I turned eighteen.
Before I turned eighteen, I was used to having a hard life. When I was first born, I had a loving family. I had a mom and two dads, and three brothers. And we were all one big happy family, or so I thought. When I was ten, something happened to cause my parents to split up. I never did find out what happened to cause it.
All I knew was that the boys and I had to go and have DNA tests done to find out which of us belonged to my dad, Sean. Unfortunately for me, I was the only one that the test showed belonged to him. So, I had to spend every weekend at his house with him. And most of my breaks from school were spent at his house. I hated it.
He was always very abusive to me, and it was mentally and emotionally most of the time. When he only had me on the weekends, he would stick to mentally and emotionally abusing me. But when I had to spend a longer amount of time with him, it would get physical. He would beat me and lock me in a closet for hours at a time, sometimes for days.
Once I turned e | When I was grieving over my miscarriage, some girl, nine months pregnant claimed that her kid belonged to my loved biker.

This is meant for people who are serious about building a career, not just exploring a side option.

Real estate, when done the right way, requires full-time commitment, consistency, and a willingness to learn. It‚Äôs not easy, but for the right person, it can be a meaningful long-term path with real ownership and growth.

At Colorado Property Group, we focus on doing this business the right way. We value accountability, collaboration, and contribution. The people who thrive here are curious, coachable, and willing to put in the work over time.

This path isn‚Äôt for everyone, and that‚Äôs okay. But for someone who is ready to commit and wants to grow in the right environment, it can be incredibly rewarding.

Predictable qualified leads‚Ä¶

That's what scales your business.

I've seen it over and over again across hundreds of businesses.

A business spends $100k, $200k, $400k on leads that will never close.. Then they install a Qualified Lead System and they scale their business profitably.

I'll help you install this system to increase your lead quality basically over night, and give you a strategy and system to scale your advertising past 7 figures while removing yourself from the process.

Most of my clients have media buyers or agencies, but they don‚Äôt typically come with a scaling strategy.

They focus on cost per lead, but that doesn't put qualified leads on your closers' calendars, and any feedback just leads the marketing team to point fingers toward sales.

Which pulls you back in the weeds and out of solving higher level problems in your business.

This isn't always the advertisers fault, and you might not have to fire them.

But this doesn't fix itself, and the stakes get higher the longer you wait.

Good news is right now.. it‚Äôs way easier to get higher lead quality than it‚Äôs ever been.

Chapter 1 Time Travel
"We're getting a divorce."

"I married you to fulfill my grandfather's dying wish. Audrey is the only one I truly love."

"Owen, I love you. Losing you will kill me."

"Fine, then just don't die on me."

Nerissa Jamison suddenly jolted awake, sweat beading across her forehead. She was gasping for breath.

The room was huge, decorated in lavish, palatial style, rich and extravagant.

Staring around at the unfamiliar surroundings, Nerissa froze for a moment. 'What's going on? I remember I died,' she wondered.

At the same time, a flood of new memories poured into her mind.

She saw a man glaring at a woman with utter disgust as the woman collapsed to the floor, begging him not to divorce her.

After about ten minutes, Nerissa finally pieced together her situation.

Clearly, she had traveled through time.

The girl in the memories was also named Nerissa. She was born in the slums with no notable background, and her parents were unknown.

Right after birth, she was abandoned by the roadside in a village. An elderly local found her and raised her.

Six months ago, this ordinary village girl married into the Calloway family in Aosthorne. From there, she climbed the social ladder to become a wealthy wife envied by all.

All of this was thanks to something that happened a year ago.

A year ago, Griffin suddenly suffered a seizure and fell into the water while struggling. Nerissa happened to be nearby and saved him.

When they met for the first time, Griffin was deeply impressed by Nerissa. For one, she was beautiful. But more importantly, he believed Nerissa brought good luck.

At the time, Calloway Group was facing an unprecedented financial crisis.

To repay Nerissa for saving him and to save the nearly bankrupt company, Griffin ignored opposition and insisted that his grandson, Owen Calloway, marry Nerissa.

After Nerissa and Owen married, Calloway Group, on the brink of collapse, suddenly secured several large orders and not only survived but thriv | Chapter 1 Time Travel

Chapter 1 Being Forced To Marry
Stacey Crowell and her husband, Brent Crowell, were about to move to their new house.

While rummaging through Brent's safe, Stacey stumbled upon a bunch of old remittance slips hidden in the corner. They stretched back over several years.

Every single one was sent to the same person, Candice Thornton. She was Brent's first love.

Stacey couldn't help but feel a bit uneasy. She thought, 'How many years has it been since Brent broke up with Candice? They've both moved on and had their own families. Candice's youngest kid must be out of college by now, and yet they're still keeping in touch?'

On the way to their new place, Stacey couldn't hold back anymore. She asked Brent, "Have you been financially supporting Candice all these years?"

Brent's expression shifted when he saw the remittance slips in her hand, but he didn't try to hide anything. "Her husband passed away over ten years ago. She's been left to support her parents and two kids all by herself. She's barely scraping by, and on top of that, she got hepatitis.

"I think she only reached out to me because she had no other options. Back in the day, her parents helped me out when I was down, so I figured I owed her one.

"We've built our company up over the years and made a lot of money. This is just pocket change for us. Don't let it bother you, okay?"

Seeing how honest Brent was, Stacey let it go. She figured Brent was just repaying the Thornton family for their kindness. Besides, they'd been married for years, so she didn't want to make a big deal out of it.

She said, "But I don't want you to keep supporting her. You can't help her forever."

Anyway, Stacey just never liked Candice.

Brent agreed.

Just then, out of nowhere, a massive truck suddenly veered out of control and charged straight at their car.

In the chaos, Stacey watched in horror as she and Brent were hurled through the air.

When Stacey opened her eyes again, she heard a harsh voice. "Carrie, what do you mea | CHAPTER 1
My Sweet Little Luna,

It‚Äôs been far too long since I‚Äôve seen that pretty scowl of yours. I wonder, does it deepen when you read my words? Do you bite that plush bottom lip, trying to hide the way I make you squirm?

You fight me so deliciously, Sorin. If only you knew how much it excites me.

But I digress. I grow impatient. I tire of these games you play, these futile little rejections. You will be mine. Whether you come to me willingly or not is up to you, but I do hope you choose the former.

P.S. When will you stop pretending your heart belongs to someone else? It‚Äôs adorable, really.

Your King,

Alaric Hayes

The bastard wrote me another letter.

I stare at the parchment, the King‚Äôs seal mocking me with its regal wax imprint. A part of me debates just setting it on fire‚Äîright here on my damn desk‚Äîbut I know better.

The last time I ignored one of Alaric Hayes‚Äô letters, I found an entire set of warriors stationed outside my window, watching me like I was some kind of elusive prey.

Obsessed freak.

‚ÄúWhat a prick,‚Äù I mutter, rolling up my reply with far more force than necessary. 

His letters makes my blood boil, and not for the reasons he likely hoped. This man isn‚Äôt just brazen; he‚Äôs goddamn reckless. If Wade ever caught wind of these exchanges, there‚Äôd be blood spilled. 

The kind that didn‚Äôt wash out easily.

‚ÄúPretty little scowl? Plush bottom lips? Is this a fucking joke?‚Äù I mutter, crumpling the paper slightly before forcing myself to smooth it out. Destroying his words would be giving him the satisfaction of knowing he got under my skin.

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs see how you like this, your Majesty,‚Äù I say under my breath, dipping my pen into the inkpot on my desk. My handwriting, usually neat, looks like it‚Äôs been attacked by my frustration as I scribble out my response:

‚ÄúAlpha Hayes,

Your theatrics are wasted on me.

Abandoned as a child, abused in boarding school, and a-ssaulted at thirteen‚Äîat seventeen I was forced to return to my parents‚Äô and brothers‚Äô mansion with my son.
Alex, my brother, stepped forward, his eyes glistening with unshed tears. 
‚ÄúMe and Teo have been looking for you for the past four years,‚Äù he said, his voice thick with emotion. 
His words hit me like a gentle shockÔºåmy brothers had been searching for me all this time.
A faint warmth spread through my chest, chasing away some of the chill of fear. 
But joy turned to agony when they learned my son was three, and realized what had happened to me at thirteen.
Alex‚Äôs fist hit the wall with a crash. Teo just shook his head, face ashen.
Guilt overwhelmed both of them, their shoulders hunched under the weight of it.
 For the first time, someone in this family seemed to grasp the horror I‚Äôd endured.
‚ÄúWe've let you down,‚Äù Teo murmured.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry,‚Äù Alex said, his gaze earnest. 
I whispered, ‚ÄúI believe you.‚Äù
For the first time in years, I felt a glimmer of something like belonging.

The very day I found out that my life was about to end, Alpha Derek Greenwood, my husband, was staying with another she-wolf.
„ÄÄI was lying in the hospital bed when Orson Romero came in with my medical report. "Tabitha, when did you get hurt?" he asked.

„ÄÄOrson was the doctor for the Red Moon Pack and my classmate from werewolf school.
"Your abdominal wound isn't healing as it should. For a werewolf, even serious injuries start patching up in about three days," Orson told me, his expression grave. Then he asked, "So how did you get hurt exactly?"
"In an attack on my father's pack by rogues. Both my dad and I got injured," I replied, staring at the floor.
„ÄÄDad's business was slow, so I came home for a visit. That was when the rogues raided the Silver Moon Pack all of a sudden.
„ÄÄThey were extremely cruel and savage.
„ÄÄFortunately, the other pack members escaped serious harm. Only Dad's head and my abdomen were wounded.
„ÄÄI had expected a swift recovery, but to my surprise, I found myself getting weaker.
„ÄÄSnapping back to reality, I looked up at Orson and asked, "When will I get better?"
"Well, can't give you a concrete answer on that one. You gotta have a thorough check-up once you're admitted. And I needa snag a sample from that wound for testing. Your wolf's hanging on by a thread, might be the wolfsbane doing a number on it. If things go on like this, you could be in real danger," Orson explained. "I'll get you admitted pronto."
"No. Dad's out cold, and I can't just up and vanish." I turned him down.
„ÄÄOrson tried to say more, but I cut in, "Keep this under wraps, okay? I don't want my family freaking out."
"Alright. I'll zip it. Hey, you're the pack's Luna, right? Stick close to your mate, that'll help," he reassured me.
„ÄÄI gave a bitter smile upon hearing what he said. Having no intention of continuing this topic, I strode out of the hospital.

When I was grieving over my miscarriage, some girl, nine months pregnant claimed that her kid belonged to my loved biker.
"I was looking for Shadow. He has the right to know about the child's existence..." 
Shadow joined the military when he was eighteen, and I had barely seen him since then.
He said no one else had ever been on his bike. I couldn't believe he betrayed me.
"If you continued to make false claims that he would get a DNA test done and then file charges against you." My voice cracked. 
"I haven't lied about anything!" 
I just needed some time. I knew that he would be pissed at me for leaving him. 
But at the time, I thought that it was the right thing to do.

Tulip
My name is Tulip Ivy Sterling, and I am 23 years old. My life has been one big trial of ups and downs. And I have to say, there have been more downs than ups. Especially over the last few years. And it has been so hard. Harder than what I had thought that my life would be after I turned eighteen.
Before I turned eighteen, I was used to having a hard life. When I was first born, I had a loving family. I had a mom and two dads, and three brothers. And we were all one big happy family, or so I thought. When I was ten, something happened to cause my parents to split up. I never did find out what happened to cause it.
All I knew was that the boys and I had to go and have DNA tests done to find out which of us belonged to my dad, Sean. Unfortunately for me, I was the only one that the test showed belonged to him. So, I had to spend every weekend at his house with him. And most of my breaks from school were spent at his house. I hated it.
He was always very abusive to me, and it was mentally and emotionally most of the time. When he only had me on the weekends, he would stick to mentally and emotionally abusing me. But when I had to spend a longer amount of time with him, it would get physical. He would beat me and lock me in a closet for hours at a time, sometimes for days.

Tulip
My name is Tulip Ivy Sterling, and I am 23 years old. My life has been one big trial of ups and downs. And I have to say, there have been more downs than ups. Especially over the last few years. And it has been so hard. Harder than what I had thought that my life would be after I turned eighteen.

I have been in touch with the Assisted Dying Group, and they will send a doctor to assess me for a quick and durable death. I saw a cardiologist last week and she confirmed - once again - that my situation is terminal. She was from Manchester in the UK, and the previous week, she had taken her son to see Oasis in Melbourne.

I am not afraid of dying, but I am afraid of living this way for much longer.

A few days ago, Razor was fired from his position as the All Blacks' head coach; so there are people, as well as me, who are in a really bad way. It's a tragic thing to be fired from your lifetime dream.

I have thoroughly enjoyed most of my life, but I was badly ripped off by a business partner around 25 years ago. Were I not to die, I would have to live with ruminating thoughts about this situation for the rest of my days. I gave him his start in business and everything I had, and he turned around and stole everything he could. Some people believe their own press kits, which they wrote themselves. These days, he promotes himself as some sort of crown prince, as if he hung the moon himself.

I have found that the best thing to do with an impending death is to dream a lot. This helps press the bad thoughts out. Poetry also helps; it is a beautiful thing.

I read about Jorge Luis Borges, the famed South American literary giant - blind, I believe, and a writing genius. He says that when he was a kid, his father would pace up and down while reading poetry. Young Jorge couldn't understand the words, but he felt that something was happening to his whole body, mind, and spirit. It wasn't happening at an intellectual level. Maybe this is what the Aborigines call "Dreamtime." Any state that takes you out of your own thoughts has got to be a good thing, right?

I have always believed in the power of poetry. Composing a poem is sometimes all that one can do when one is in an untenable situation.

It's not that I am throwing in the towel with this "death trip." The whole process

The Divorce
The small law office smelled faintly of dust and old paper. A flickering lamp in the corner gave off a weak, tired glow, casting shadows across the stacks of files lining the shelves.

I sat across from Mr. Ricci, an older man with sharp glasses and sharper instincts.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre sure about this, Mrs. Russo?‚Äù he asked quietly, hands folded over the folder in front of him.

The name sounded strange, like it belonged to someone else.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù I said, my voice steady even though my pulse wasn‚Äôt. ‚ÄúI want the divorce filed quietly. I don‚Äôt want my husband or his people knowing until everything‚Äôs finalized.‚Äù

Ricci gave me a long, measuring look, but he didn‚Äôt question me further. Instead, he slid the paperwork towards me.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôll need his signature on these.‚Äù

I nodded, slipping the papers into my leather folder. 

When I came back to the Russo mansion, it felt too quiet. The guards at the gate didn't even spare me a second glance as I walked in. No one here paid me any attention now that I was reduced to the side piece in my own marriage. And the worst part? The worst part was my husband didn't even care. 

Knowing he would be in the study, I moved towards it and was proven right when Alessia's laughter tinkled out through the half open door. These days, where Alessia was, my husband wasn't too far away. 

"‚Äîso funny," Alessia, my husband's childhood best friend, who was back in the city after her divorce was saying. 

"I know, I'm the best," came Dominic's reply, his tone the most casual and relaxed I'd ever heard it be. 

On instinct, I opened the study door all the way through and stepped inside. 

Dominic Russo froze with his whisky glass halfway to his mouth as he looked at me standing in the doorway, his smile dropping at once. 

"Oh, hey, Isabella! You're back from your studio already?" Alessia said, her perfectly painted lips pulling into a broad smile as she looked at me.
