Abigail Vossen's furious voice echoed through the dining room. "Starting today, you have nothing to do with the Vossen family.

"Take your things and get out. No wonder I've always hated you. Turns out you were never my daughter in the first place."

Ophelia Vossen hadn't even finished her breakfast when Abigail slammed a stack of personal documents onto the table in front of her.

The reason for Abigail's hatred was simple. Ophelia had lived for eighteen years as her daughter, enjoying the wealth and status of the Vossen family, while Abigail's real daughter had suffered in poverty, raised by a janitor's family.

"I understand." Ophelia's tone was flat as she neatly slipped the documents into her black handbag.

Just then, the maid Mia spoke up. "Ophelia, everything you own was provided by Mr. and Mrs. Vossen. You have no right to take anything from this house. May I check your bag?"

Reminded by Mia, Abigail immediately nodded. "Yes. Check her bag."

Cameron Vossen, seated at the head of the table, finally intervened, "That's enough. Look at the size of that bag? What could she possibly take?"

Even if Ophelia wasn't his daughter, she had lived in this home for eighteen years. Cameron couldn't help but feel a little sympathy.

But Ophelia didn't care. She turned the bag upside down, dumping everything onto the table.

"There's nothing in here except the laptop I bought with my scholarship money and an old phone. If you want them, you can have them," she said calmly.

From Ophelia's childhood, Abigail had been cold toward Ophelia. Abigail doted only on her sons, leaving Ophelia to fend for herself.

Ophelia had never spent the family's money; she even turned over her scholarship funds to the household. Nothing in this house truly belonged to her, and she had no desire to take any of it.

Abigail scoffed at her defiant tone, "Scholarship money? If we hadn't paid for your tuition at Dunhollow University, would you have even gotten a scholarship?"

"Mom, let it go. It | Abigail Vossen's furious voice echoed through the dining room. "Starting today, you have nothing to do with the Vossen family.

"There's nothing in here except the laptop I bought with my scholarship money and an old phone. If you want them, you can have them," she said calmly.

From Ophelia's childhood, Abigail had been cold toward Ophelia. Abigail doted only on her sons, leaving Ophelia to fend for herself.

Ophelia had never spent the family's money; she even turned over her scholarship funds to the household. Nothing in this house truly belonged to her, and she had no desire to take any of it.

Abigail scoffed at her defiant tone, "Scholarship money? If we hadn't paid for your tuition at Dunhollow University, would you have even gotten a scholarship?"

"Mom, let it go. It | Abigail Vossen's furious voice echoed through the dining room. "Starting today, you have nothing to do with the Vossen family.

"Take your things and get out. No wonder I've always hated you. Turns out you were never my daughter in the first place."

Ophelia Vossen hadn't even finished her breakfast when Abigail slammed a stack of personal documents onto the table in front of her.

The reason for Abigail's hatred was simple. Ophelia had lived for eighteen years as her daughter, enjoying the wealth and status of the Vossen family, while Abigail's real daughter had suffered in poverty, raised by a janitor's family.

"I understand." Ophelia's tone was flat as she neatly slipped the documents into her black handbag.

Just then, the maid Mia spoke up. "Ophelia, everything you own was provided by Mr. and Mrs. Vossen. You have no right to take anything from this house. May I check your bag?"

Reminded by Mia, Abigail immediately nodded. "Yes. Check her bag."

She's at the hospital right now!"The words had barely left his mouth before chaos erupted‚Äîchairs scraping, heels clacking, people rushing for the door.It wasn't an exaggeration to say Lydia Wallace was the it girl of their circle‚Äîbeautiful, talented, fragile in that heartbreaking way that made people want to protect her. Everyone adored her, pitied her, worshipped her.And now that their goddess was hurt?No one had the heart to keep celebrating a proposal everyone already knew the answer to.Even the guy proposing dropped everything and bolted."Jasper‚Äî"The voice that called his name came from behind‚Äîsoft, barely more than a breath.That was when everyone finally realized: the woman being proposed to hadn't said a single word this whole time.Somebody must've hit the lights in the chaos, because the room dimmed. The only glow came from the soft wall lights.In the corner, half in shadow, half in light, stood Claudia Lancaster. When I was grieving over my miscarriage, some girl, nine months pregnant claimed that her kid belonged to my loved biker.
"I was looking for Shadow. He has the right to know about the child's existence..." 
Shadow joined the military when he was eighteen, and I had barely seen him since then.
He said no one else had ever been on his bike. I couldn't believe he betrayed me.
"If you continued to make false claims that he would get a DNA test done and then file charges against you." My voice cracked. 
"I haven't lied about anything!" 
I just needed some time. I knew that he would be pissed at me for leaving him. 
But at the time, I thought that it was the right thing to do.
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

Tulip
My name is Tulip Ivy Sterling, and I am 23 years old. My life has been one big trial of ups and downs. And I have to say, there have been more downs than ups. Especially over the last few years. And it has been so hard. Harder than what I had thought that my life would be after I turned eighteen.
Before I turned eighteen, I was used to having a hard life. When I was first born, I had a loving family. I had a mom and two dads, and three brothers. And we were all one big happy family, or so I thought. When I was ten, something happened to cause my parents to split up. I never did find out what happened to cause it.
All I knew was that the boys and I had to go and have DNA tests done to find out which of us belonged to my dad, Sean. Unfortunately for me, I was the only one that the test showed belonged to him. So, I had to spend every weekend at his house with him. And most of my breaks from school were spent at his house. I hated it.
He was always very abusive to me, and it was mentally and emotionally most of the time. When he only had me on the weekends, he would stick to mentally and emotionally abusing me. But when I had to spend a longer amount of time with him, it would get physical. He would beat me and lock me in a closet for hours at a time, sometimes for days.

Chapter 1Bang!The doors to the event room burst open."Something happened to Lydia!" a man shouted as he stumbled in, panic all over his face.The words hit like a bomb.The room‚Äîdecked out in flowers, ribbons, and romantic music, buzzing with excitement over the proposal‚Äîinstantly went still.The man in the spotlight, still down on one knee, ring in hand, spun around in shock."What did you just say?"Quade Zimmer, his blue-dyed hair as loud as his voice, blurted, "Mrs. Lancaster just called‚ÄîLydia's been in a car accident! She's at the hospital right now!"The words had barely left his mouth before chaos erupted‚Äîchairs scraping, heels clacking, people rushing for the door.It wasn't an exaggeration to say Lydia Wallace was the it girl of their circle‚Äîbeautiful, talented, fragile in that heartbreaking way that made people want to protect her. Everyone adored her, pitied her, worshipped her.And now that their goddess was hurt?No one had the heart to keep celebrating a proposal everyone already knew the answer to.Even the guy proposing dropped everything and bolted."Jasper‚Äî"The voice that called his name came from behind‚Äîsoft, barely more than a breath.That was when everyone finally realized: the woman being proposed to hadn't said a single word this whole time.Somebody must've hit the lights in the chaos, because the room dimmed. The only glow came from the soft wall lights.In the corner, half in shadow, half in light, stood Claudia Lancaster. Her beauty wasn't the sweet, gentle kind‚Äîit was sharp, striking, unforgettable.But right now, her calm was unnerving. Her expression gave away nothing."You don't want to hear my answer?" she asked quietly.Just a minute ago, Jasper Fenton had asked her to marry him.Now, halfway out the door, he froze.He didn't even try to explain. "Claudia, I'm sorry. I have to go to the hospital. Go home first, okay?""What if I don't let you go?" Her voice stayed steady. "Jasper, you know I hate her."Jasper sighed, exasperated. "Claudia, not now. When I was grieving over my miscarriage, some girl, nine months pregnant claimed that her kid belonged to my loved biker.
"I was looking for Shadow. He has the right to know about the child's existence..." 
Shadow joined the military when he was eighteen, and I had barely seen him since then.
He said no one else had ever been on his bike. I couldn't believe he betrayed me.
"If you continued to make false claims that he would get a DNA test done and then file charges against you." My voice cracked. 
"I haven't lied about anything!" 
I just needed some time. I knew that he would be pissed at me for leaving him. 
But at the time, I thought that it was the right thing to do.
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

Tulip
My name is Tulip Ivy Sterling, and I am 23 years old. My life has been one big trial of ups and downs. And I have to say, there have been more downs than ups. Especially over the last few years. And it has been so hard. Harder than what I had thought that my life would be after I turned eighteen.
Before I turned eighteen, I was used to having a hard life. When I was first born, I had a loving family. I had a mom and two dads, and three brothers. And we were all one big happy family, or so I thought. When I was ten, something happened to cause my parents to split up. I never did find out what happened to cause it.
All I knew was that the boys and I had to go and have DNA tests done to find out which of us belonged to my dad, Sean. Unfortunately for me, I was the only one that the test showed belonged to him. So, I had to spend every weekend at his house with him. And most of my breaks from school were spent at his house. I hated it.
He was always very abusive to me, and it was mentally and emotionally most of the time. When he only had me on the weekends, he would stick to mentally and emotionally abusing me. But when I had to spend a longer amount of time with him, it would get physical. He would beat me and lock me in a closet for hours at a time, sometimes for days.
Once I turned e | When I was grieving over my miscarriage, some girl, nine months pregnant claimed that her kid belonged to my loved biker.
"I was looking for Shadow. He has the right to know about the child's existence..."

"I haven't lied about anything!" 
I just needed some time. I knew that he would be pissed at me for leaving him. 
But at the time, I thought that it was the right thing to do.

Abandoned as a child, abused in boarding school, and a-ssaulted at thirteen‚Äîat seventeen I was forced to return to my parents‚Äô and brothers‚Äô mansion with my son.
Alex, my brother, stepped forward, his eyes glistening with unshed tears. 
‚ÄúMe and Teo have been looking for you for the past four years,‚Äù he said, his voice thick with emotion. 
His words hit me like a gentle shockÔºåmy brothers had been searching for me all this time.
A faint warmth spread through my chest, chasing away some of the chill of fear. 
But joy turned to agony when they learned my son was three, and realized what had happened to me at thirteen.
Alex‚Äôs fist hit the wall with a crash. Teo just shook his head, face ashen.
Guilt overwhelmed both of them, their shoulders hunched under the weight of it.
 For the first time, someone in this family seemed to grasp the horror I‚Äôd endured.
‚ÄúWe've let you down,‚Äù Teo murmured.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry,‚Äù Alex said, his gaze earnest. 
I whispered, ‚ÄúI believe you.‚Äù
For the first time in years, I felt a glimmer of something like belonging.

Oh sh-it.
I sat frozen in my place. My 17-year-old but, which has seen better, and worse days was numb from not moving for a few hours so I couldn't have been sure whether someone stitched it to the uncomfortable leather seat. It would explain my lack of movement, right?
Wrong.
It was the pair of green eyes, staring down at me, completely shocked. It was my pair of eyes staring down at me in shock.
Funny, the last time I saw the eyes, they were filled with disgust and hatred. I took in his tall figure with masculine appearance in formal clothes, not a suit though, which I have honestly expected when I was told he was coming down here.
I slowly blinked at him, realising I was, in fact, not paralyzed. Good. That was the impulse I needed to clear my throat and stand up awkwardly. He was tall. Too tall. But honestly, due to my up bringing, everyone was taller than me.
"Morning," I said coldly to him. He kept staring. I gave  | After the charity gala, I caught my husband cheating on me with his VP of Marketing.
A low, intimate laugh came from Derek's locked office.
I froze, an earring slipping from my finger. The sound came from his private office, the one even the cleaning staff locked.
I approached, bracing myself for something unknown.
"Charlie doesn't understand me the way you do."
I heard Derek's gentle, intimate voice when I was only three feet from the door.
Then it was her.
Vivian Clarke. 
His VP of Marketing.
Wearing the dress I'd complimented hours earlier‚Äîsitting on his desk, his hand on her waist, intimately.
I didn't gasp. Instead, I stood there for a full three seconds, with a shock-stricken calm, meticulously recording every detail.
The way her fingers were twirling in his hair. The lipstick mark on his collar.The champagne gla-sses on his desk two of them, half-empty, celebratory.
Then I closed the door. Carefully, silently. So quietly that they didn't even notice.
He's a hero in their eyes. A visionary. A godda-mn saint.
And I'm the idiot who believed him.
This perfect life is a lie, and I‚Äôm done playing along.

The diamonds feel heavier coming off than they did going on.
I stand in front of the bathroom mirror, fingers working the clasp of the Cartier necklace Derrick gave me for our fifth anniversary. The woman staring back at me looks like she belongs in a magazine spread sleek updo, perfect makeup, designer gown that probably cost more than most people's monthly mortgage. But her eyes are tired. No, not tired. Empty.
I finally get the necklace undone and set it on the marble counter with a soft clink. The sound echoes in the cavernous bathroom, all gleaming fixtures and heated floors. This penthouse has everything. Everything except the one thing I actually need a husband who looks at me like I matter.

The way her fingers were twirling in his hair. The lipstick mark on his collar.The champagne gla-sses on his desk two of them, half-empty, celebratory.
Then I closed the door. Carefully, silently. So quietly that they didn't even notice.

Chapter 1Bang!The doors to the event room burst open."Something happened to Lydia!" a man shouted as he stumbled in, panic all over his face.The words hit like a bomb.The room‚Äîdecked out in flowers, ribbons, and romantic music, buzzing with excitement over the proposal‚Äîinstantly went still.The man in the spotlight, still down on one knee, ring in hand, spun around in shock."What did you just say?"Quade Zimmer, his blue-dyed hair as loud as his voice, blurted, "Mrs. Lancaster just called‚ÄîLydia's been in a car accident! She's at the hospital right now!"The words had barely left his mouth before chaos erupted‚Äîchairs scraping, heels clacking, people rushing for the door.It wasn't an exaggeration to say Lydia Wallace was the it girl of their circle‚Äîbeautiful, talented, fragile in that heartbreaking way that made people want to protect her. Everyone adored her, pitied her, worshipped her.And now that their goddess was hurt?No one had the heart to keep celebrating a proposal everyone already knew the answer to.Even the guy proposing dropped everything and bolted."Jasper‚Äî"The voice that called his name came from behind‚Äîsoft, barely more than a breath.That was when everyone finally realized: the woman being proposed to hadn't said a single word this whole time.Somebody must've hit the lights in the chaos, because the room dimmed. The only glow came from the soft wall lights.In the corner, half in shadow, half in light, stood Claudia Lancaster. Her beauty wasn't the sweet, gentle kind‚Äîit was sharp, striking, unforgettable.But right now, her calm was unnerving. Her expression gave away nothing."You don't want to hear my answer?" she asked quietly.Just a minute ago, Jasper Fenton had asked her to marry him.Now, halfway out the door, he froze.He didn't even try to explain. "Claudia, I'm sorry. I have to go to the hospital. Go home first, okay?""What if I don't let you go?" Her voice stayed steady. "Jasper, you know I hate her."Jasper sighed, exasperated. "Claudia, not now. When I was grieving over my miscarriage, some girl, nine months pregnant claimed that her kid belonged to my loved biker.
"I was looking for Shadow. He has the right to know about the child's existence..." 
Shadow joined the military when he was eighteen, and I had barely seen him since then.
He said no one else had ever been on his bike. I couldn't believe he betrayed me.
"If you continued to make false claims that he would get a DNA test done and then file charges against you." My voice cracked. 
"I haven't lied about anything!" 
I just needed some time. I knew that he would be pissed at me for leaving him. 
But at the time, I thought that it was the right thing to do.
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

Tulip
My name is Tulip Ivy Sterling, and I am 23 years old. My life has been one big trial of ups and downs. And I have to say, there have been more downs than ups. Especially over the last few years. And it has been so hard. Harder than what I had thought that my life would be after I turned eighteen.
Before I turned eighteen, I was used to having a hard life. When I was first born, I had a loving family. I had a mom and two dads, and three brothers. And we were all one big happy family, or so I thought. When I was ten, something happened to cause my parents to split up. I never did find out what happened to cause it.
All I knew was that the boys and I had to go and have DNA tests done to find out which of us belonged to my dad, Sean. Unfortunately for me, I was the only one that the test showed belonged to him. So, I had to spend every weekend at his house with him. And most of my breaks from school were spent at his house. I hated it.
He was always very abusive to me, and it was mentally and emotionally most of the time. When he only had me on the weekends, he would stick to mentally and emotionally abusing me. But when I had to spend a longer amount of time with him, it would get physical. He would beat me and lock me in a closet for hours at a time, sometimes for days.
Once I turned e | When I was grieving over my miscarriage, some girl, nine months pregnant claimed that her kid belonged to my loved biker.

But at the time, I thought that it was the right thing to do.

"Honey... mmm... I'm tired... no more..."
At three in the morning, I push against the man's lean, moving waist,
only for him to grab my wrist and flip me over, his voice low and rough,
"Shut up and stay down! I'm not finished yet... just bear with it a little longer..."
I clench my eyes shut, swallowing my moans.
This might be the last time I sleep with him‚Äîthis very morning, I secretly visited a law firm and drafted divorce papers behind his back.
Our marriage was a matter of convenience, a business deal, plain and simple.
For me, it was security. For him, it was proof of a legal identity.
Three years married,
he likes having s*x with me, but he doesn't like me.
There was a time when Dominic couldn't keep his hands off me.
He'd pull me into dimly lit hallways and steal kisses during family gatherings.
I thought,
maybe someday I could make him love me too.
But when Alessia reappeared in our lives, and his late-night meetings doubled, I lost all hope.
Dominic's rough kisses leave me burning, the fading heat from my last climax already threatening to return.
Then a ringtone cuts through‚Äîand he suddenly stills.
Glancing at the caller ID, he pulls out of me without hesitation, still hard, and answers the phone, his voice uncharacteristically soft,
"Alessia, what's wrong? Don't cry. I'll be right there."
Unspeakable frustration twists inside me.
With a tear-choked voice, I beg him, "Please‚Ä¶ don't go‚Ä¶"
Dominic doesn't respond.
Helplessness, ache, and the sting of rejection flood my chest‚Äîmixed with something deeper than desire, more like grief‚Ä¶
"Wait‚Äîbefore you go, I just need you to sign a few documents."
I call out hoarsely,
climbing off the bed and pulling the divorce papers from my bag, quickly flipping to the signature page.
"What's this?" Dominic frowns at the documents.
"Just some safety liability forms for a new project I‚Äôm starting with a company," I say, sliding the papers across the glossy wooden table toward him.

In the heartland where rustic routines and predictable landscapes often prevailed, Saphira was a whisper of novelty that danced on the breeze, defying the clich√©s of a behindhand place.

This small town was no ordinary collection of homes; it was a tapestry of pristine, cobblestone paths, quaint mini-mansions that whispered tales of cozy comfort, and log cabins adorned with designer flair.

Tucked away at the serene base of a slumbering mountain, a vision arrested your gaze: a contemporary courtyard that stood as a testament to architectural harmony. It was a fusion of minimalist elegance and style, where tradition met modernity in a seamless blend.

And what a revelation it was to learn that the architect of this masterpiece was Cherise Leach, a young woman on the cusp of her twenties.

In the courtyard, a young guy with a youthful face looked around, his eyes big and full of amazement. "Wow, this looks like a picture from a book, the new kind of town. Are there any secret experts here?"

This little guy was Yves Leach, the baby of the Leach family from Betrico. Ever since he arrived in Saphira, he'd been exploring like he'd found a brand new place.

"Andy, didn't Shirley say this place was all broken down and the people were having a tough time? But check out these houses! They're building fancy villas. This spot is even cooler than our Leach manor!" Yves chirped, his teenage energy buzzing.

At the tender age of thirteen, he was a walking, talking chatterbox.

"Yves, take a seat and stay out of trouble," Andy Leach, Yves's cousin, instructed, his eyes scanning the bustling courtyard with a touch of confusion.

He shifted his attention to Dennis Young, one of the housekeepers here. "Any idea when Cherise will arrive?"

Right on time, the courtyard's wooden door groaned open, and a tall figure stepped in, bathed in sunlight, moving with a natural elegance.

As she drew closer, Yves couldn't help but exclaim, "Wow, I think we've got a fairy here!"

Everyone adored her, pitied her, worshipped her.And now that their goddess was hurt?No one had the heart to keep celebrating a proposal everyone already knew the answer to.Even the guy proposing dropped everything and bolted."Jasper‚Äî"The voice that called his name came from behind‚Äîsoft, barely more than a breath.That was when everyone finally realized: the woman being proposed to hadn't said a single word this whole time.Somebody must've hit the lights in the chaos, because the room dimmed. The only glow came from the soft wall lights.In the corner, half in shadow, half in light, stood Claudia Lancaster. Her beauty wasn't the sweet, gentle kind‚Äîit was sharp, striking, unforgettable.But right now, her calm was unnerving. When I was grieving over my miscarriage, some girl, nine months pregnant claimed that her kid belonged to my loved biker.
"I was looking for Shadow. He has the right to know about the child's existence..." 
Shadow joined the military when he was eighteen, and I had barely seen him since then.
He said no one else had ever been on his bike. I couldn't believe he betrayed me.
"If you continued to make false claims that he would get a DNA test done and then file charges against you." My voice cracked. 
"I haven't lied about anything!" 
I just needed some time. I knew that he would be pissed at me for leaving him. 
But at the time, I thought that it was the right thing to do.
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

Tulip
My name is Tulip Ivy Sterling, and I am 23 years old. My life has been one big trial of ups and downs. And I have to say, there have been more downs than ups. Especially over the last few years. And it has been so hard. Harder than what I had thought that my life would be after I turned eighteen.
Before I turned eighteen, I was used to having a hard life. When I was first born, I had a loving family. I had a mom and two dads, and three brothers. And we were all one big happy family, or so I thought. When I was ten, something happened to cause my parents to split up. I never did find out what happened to cause it.
All I knew was that the boys and I had to go and have DNA tests done to find out which of us belonged to my dad, Sean. Unfortunately for me, I was the only one that the test showed belonged to him. So, I had to spend every weekend at his house with him. And most of my breaks from school were spent at his house. I hated it.
He was always very abusive to me, and it was mentally and emotionally most of the time. When he only had me on the weekends, he would stick to mentally and emotionally abusing me. But when I had to spend a longer amount of time with him, it would get physical. He would beat me and lock me in a closet for hours at a time, sometimes for days.
Once I turned e | When I was grieving over my miscarriage, some girl, nine months pregnant claimed that her kid belonged to my loved biker.

Abandoned as a child, abused in boarding school, and a-ssaulted at thirteen‚Äîat seventeen I was forced to return to my parents‚Äô and brothers‚Äô mansion with my son.
Alex, my brother, stepped forward, his eyes glistening with unshed tears. 
‚ÄúMe and Teo have been looking for you for the past four years,‚Äù he said, his voice thick with emotion. 
His words hit me like a gentle shockÔºåmy brothers had been searching for me all this time.
A faint warmth spread through my chest, chasing away some of the chill of fear. 
But joy turned to agony when they learned my son was three, and realized what had happened to me at thirteen.
Alex‚Äôs fist hit the wall with a crash. Teo just shook his head, face ashen.
Guilt overwhelmed both of them, their shoulders hunched under the weight of it.
 For the first time, someone in this family seemed to grasp the horror I‚Äôd endured.
‚ÄúWe've let you down,‚Äù Teo murmured.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry,‚Äù Alex said, his gaze earnest. 
I whispered, ‚ÄúI believe you.‚Äù
For the first time in years, I felt a glimmer of something like belonging.

I sat frozen in my place. My 17-year-old but, which has seen better, and worse days was numb from not moving for a few hours so I couldn't have been sure whether someone stitched it to the uncomfortable leather seat. It would explain my lack of movement, right?
Wrong.

Funny, the last time I saw the eyes, they were filled with disgust and hatred. I took in his tall figure with masculine appearance in formal clothes, not a suit though, which I have honestly expected when I was told he was coming down here.
I slowly blinked at him, realising I was, in fact, not paralyzed. Good. That was the impulse I needed to clear my throat and stand up awkwardly. He was tall. Too tall. But honestly, due to my up bringing, everyone was taller than me.

After the charity gala, I caught my husband cheating on me with his VP of Marketing.
A low, intimate laugh came from Derek's locked office.
I froze, an earring slipping from my finger. The sound came from his private office, the one even the cleaning staff locked.
I approached, bracing myself for something unknown.
"Charlie doesn't understand me the way you do."
I heard Derek's gentle, intimate voice when I was only three feet from the door.
Then it was her.
Vivian Clarke. 
His VP of Marketing.
Wearing the dress I'd complimented hours earlier‚Äîsitting on his desk, his hand on her waist, intimately.
I didn't gasp. Instead, I stood there for a full three seconds, with a shock-stricken calm, meticulously recording every detail.
The way her fingers were twirling in his hair. The lipstick mark on his collar.The champagne gla-sses on his desk two of them, half-empty, celebratory.
Then I closed the door. Carefully, silently. So quietly that they didn't even notice.
He's a hero in their eyes. A visionary. A godda-mn saint.
And I'm the idiot who believed him.
This perfect life is a lie, and I‚Äôm done playing along.
‚Äî‚Äî
The diamonds feel heavier coming off than they did going on.
I stand in front of the bathroom mirror, fingers working the clasp of the Cartier necklace Derrick gave me for our fifth anniversary. The woman staring back at me looks like she belongs in a magazine spread sleek updo, perfect makeup, designer gown that probably cost more than most people's monthly mortgage. But her eyes are tired. No, not tired. Empty.
I finally get the necklace undone and set it on the marble counter with a soft clink. The sound echoes in the cavernous bathroom, all gleaming fixtures and heated floors. This penthouse has everything. Everything except the one thing I actually need a husband who looks at me like I matter.
Tonight was supposed to be special. When I was grieving over my miscarriage, some girl, nine months pregnant claimed that her kid belonged to my loved biker.
"I was looking for Shadow. He has the right to know about the child's existence..." 
Shadow joined the military when he was eighteen, and I had barely seen him since then.
He said no one else had ever been on his bike. I couldn't believe he betrayed me.
"If you continued to make false claims that he would get a DNA test done and then file charges against you." My voice cracked. 
"I haven't lied about anything!" 
I just needed some time. I knew that he would be pissed at me for leaving him. 
But at the time, I thought that it was the right thing to do.

My name is Tulip Ivy Sterling, and I am 23 years old. My life has been one big trial of ups and downs. And I have to say, there have been more downs than ups. Especially over the last few years. And it has been so hard. Harder than what I had thought that my life would be after I turned eighteen.
Before I turned eighteen, I was used to having a hard life. When I was first born, I had a loving family. I had a mom and two dads, and three brothers. And we were all one big happy family, or so I thought. When I was ten, something happened to cause my parents to split up. I never did find out what happened to cause it.
All I knew was that the boys and I had to go and have DNA tests done to find out which of us belonged to my dad, Sean. Unfortunately for me, I was the only one that the test showed belonged to him. So, I had to spend every weekend at his house with him. And most of my breaks from school were spent at his house. I hated it.
He was always very abusive to me, and it was mentally and emotionally most of the time. When he only had me on the weekends, he would stick to mentally and emotionally abusing me. But when I had to spend a longer amount of time with him, it would get physical. He would beat me and lock me in a closet for hours at a time, sometimes for days.
Once I turned e | When I was grieving over my miscarriage, some girl, nine months pregnant claimed that her kid belonged to my loved biker.

And we were all one big happy family, or so I thought. When I was ten, something happened to cause my parents to split up. I never did find out what happened to cause it.
All I knew was that the boys and I had to go and have DNA tests done to find out which of us belonged to my dad, Sean. Unfortunately for me, I was the only one that the test showed belonged to him. So, I had to spend every weekend at his house with him. And most of my breaks from school were spent at his house. I hated it.
He was always very abusive to me, and it was mentally and emotionally most of the time. When he only had me on the weekends, he would stick to mentally and emotionally abusing me. But when I had to spend a longer amount of time with him, it would get physical. He would beat me and lock me in a closet for hours at a time, sometimes for days.
Once I turned e | When I was grieving over my miscarriage, some girl, nine months pregnant claimed that her kid belonged to my loved biker.
"I was looking for Shadow. He has the right to know about the child's existence..." 
Shadow joined the military when he was eighteen, and I had barely seen him since then.
He said no one else had ever been on his bike. I couldn't believe he betrayed me.
"If you continued to make false claims that he would get a DNA test done and then file charges against you." My voice cracked. 
"I haven't lied about anything!" 
I just needed some time. I knew that he would be pissed at me for leaving him. 
But at the time, I thought that it was the right thing to do.

In the heartland where rustic routines and predictable landscapes often prevailed, Saphira was a whisper of novelty that danced on the breeze, defying the clich√©s of a behindhand place.

This small town was no ordinary collection of homes; it was a tapestry of pristine, cobblestone paths, quaint mini-mansions that whispered tales of cozy comfort, and log cabins adorned with designer flair.

Tucked away at the serene base of a slumbering mountain, a vision arrested your gaze: a contemporary courtyard that stood as a testament to architectural harmony. It was a fusion of minimalist elegance and style, where tradition met modernity in a seamless blend.

And what a revelation it was to learn that the architect of this masterpiece was Cherise Leach, a young woman on the cusp of her twenties.

In the courtyard, a young guy with a youthful face looked around, his eyes big and full of amazement. "Wow, this looks like a picture from a book, the new kind of town. Are there any secret experts here?"

This little guy was Yves Leach, the baby of the Leach family from Betrico. Ever since he arrived in Saphira, he'd been exploring like he'd found a brand new place.

"Andy, didn't Shirley say this place was all broken down and the people were having a tough time? But check out these houses! They're building fancy villas. This spot is even cooler than our Leach manor!" Yves chirped, his teenage energy buzzing.

At the tender age of thirteen, he was a walking, talking chatterbox.

"Yves, take a seat and stay out of trouble," Andy Leach, Yves's cousin, instructed, his eyes scanning the bustling courtyard with a touch of confusion.

He shifted his attention to Dennis Young, one of the housekeepers here. "Any idea when Cherise will arrive?"

Right on time, the courtyard's wooden door groaned open, and a tall figure stepped in, bathed in sunlight, moving with a natural elegance.

As she drew closer, Yves couldn't help but exclaim, "Wow, I think we've got a fairy here!"

Before I turned eighteen, I was used to having a hard life. When I was first born, I had a loving family. I had a mom and two dads, and three brothers. And we were all one big happy family, or so I thought. When I was ten, something happened to cause my parents to split up. I never did find out what happened to cause it.
All I knew was that the boys and I had to go and have DNA tests done to find out which of us belonged to my dad, Sean. Unfortunately for me, I was the only one that the test showed belonged to him. So, I had to spend every weekend at his house with him. And most of my breaks from school were spent at his house. I hated it.
He was always very abusive to me, and it was mentally and emotionally most of the time. When he only had me on the weekends, he would stick to mentally and emotionally abusing me. But when I had to spend a longer amount of time with him, it would get physical. He would beat me and lock me in a closet for hours at a time, sometimes for days.

Several parents have mentioned to us lately that there have been some really serious germs going around in the community. And honestly, we hate hearing that. Sick kids are serious business, and for many families it‚Äôs more than just a rough week‚Ä¶it can mean missed school, missed work, and a lot of stress.

That‚Äôs exactly why, from the very beginning, it was important to us to build a gym that‚Äôs easy to clean the RIGHT way. We weren't interested in massive or jam-packed with sensory-stimulating toys and experiences - because our space was intentionally designed to be safe, accessible, and supportive for neurodivergent kids‚Äîwhile still being a place where all children can play, move, and grow together. Every piece of equipment was chosen with safety and cleanliness top of mind.

Anywhere kids are automatically becomes a high-touch surface...and for us...high-touch surfaces mean even higher standards. We see the value in cleaning our gym multiple times a day, deep-cleaning toys and equipment regularly, and staying on top of the details so families can relax when they're hanging out with us. 

You won‚Äôt find broken toys or sticky surfaces here‚Äîand if you ever notice something that needs attention, we want you to tell us - we even have a special basket for dirty toys (or toys that were just TOO tempting to keep out of mouths üòâ). 

Because the only thing we ever want your child taking home is joy - and maybe a fun prize from the Rock Shop...üòâ | We Rock The Spectrum - Lakewood

Chapter 1Bang!The doors to the event room burst open."Something happened to Lydia!" a man shouted as he stumbled in, panic all over his face.The words hit like a bomb.The room‚Äîdecked out in flowers, ribbons, and romantic music, buzzing with excitement over the proposal‚Äîinstantly went still.The man in the spotlight, still down on one knee, ring in hand, spun around in shock."What did you just say?"Quade Zimmer, his blue-dyed hair as loud as his voice, blurted, "Mrs. Lancaster just called‚ÄîLydia's been in a car accident! She's at the hospital right now!"The words had barely left his mouth before chaos erupted‚Äîchairs scraping, heels clacking, people rushing for the door.It wasn't an exaggeration to say Lydia Wallace was the it girl of their circle‚Äîbeautiful, talented, fragile in that heartbreaking way that made people want to protect her. Everyone adored her, pitied her, worshipped her.And now that their goddess was hurt?No one had the heart to keep celebrating a proposal everyone already knew the answer to.Even the guy proposing dropped everything and bolted."Jasper‚Äî"The voice that called his name came from behind‚Äîsoft, barely more than a breath.That was when everyone finally realized: the woman being proposed to hadn't said a single word this whole time.Somebody must've hit the lights in the chaos, because the room dimmed. The only glow came from the soft wall lights.In the corner, half in shadow, half in light, stood Claudia Lancaster. Her beauty wasn't the sweet, gentle kind‚Äîit was sharp, striking, unforgettable.But right now, her calm was unnerving. Her expression gave away nothing."You don't want to hear my answer?" she asked quietly.Just a minute ago, Jasper Fenton had asked her to marry him.Now, halfway out the door, he froze.He didn't even try to explain. "Claudia, I'm sorry. I have to go to the hospital. Go home first, okay?""What if I don't let you go?" Her voice stayed steady. "Jasper, you know I hate her."Jasper sighed, exasperated. "Claudia, not now. Charlie Wade was an unwanted daughter left by her adoptive family in countryside 15 years ago, but her real identity as the heir of a prominent family remained a secret. Now she's grown up, she swore that one day, those who shunned her would kneel before her and beg for mercy, eventually!
=============================
Chapter 1 The Leach Family's Visit
In the heartland where rustic routines and predictable landscapes often prevailed, Saphira was a whisper of novelty that danced on the breeze, defying the clich√©s of a behindhand place.
This small town was no ordinary collection of homes; it was a tapestry of pristine, cobblestone paths, quaint mini-mansions that whispered tales of cozy comfort, and log cabins adorned with designer flair.
Tucked away at the serene base of a slumbering mountain, a vision arrested your gaze: a contemporary courtyard that stood as a testament to architectural harmony. It was a fusion of minimalist elegance and style, where tradition met modernity in a seamless blend.
And what a revelation it was to learn that the architect of this masterpiece was Cherise Leach, a young woman on the cusp of her twenties.
In the courtyard, a young guy with a youthful face looked around, his eyes big and full of amazement. 
"Wow, this looks like a picture from a book, the new kind of town. Are there any secret experts here?"
This little guy was Yves Leach, the baby of the Leach family from Betrico. Ever since he arrived in Saphira, he'd been exploring like he'd found a brand new place.
"Andy, didn't Shirley say this place was all broken down and the people were having a tough time? But check out these houses! They're building fancy villas. This spot is even cooler than our Leach manor!" Yves chirped, his teenage energy buzzing.
At the tender age of thirteen, he was a walking, talking chatterbox.
"Yves, take a seat and stay out of trouble," Andy Leach, Yves's cousin, instructed, his eyes scanning the bustling courtyard with a touch of confusion.

Chapter 1Bang!The doors to the event room burst open."Something happened to Lydia!" a man shouted as he stumbled in, panic all over his face.The words hit like a bomb.The room‚Äîdecked out in flowers, ribbons, and romantic music, buzzing with excitement over the proposal‚Äîinstantly went still.The man in the spotlight, still down on one knee, ring in hand, spun around in shock."What did you just say?"Quade Zimmer, his blue-dyed hair as loud as his voice, blurted, "Mrs. Lancaster just called‚ÄîLydia's been in a car accident! She's at the hospital right now!"The words had barely left his mouth before chaos erupted‚Äîchairs scraping, heels clacking, people rushing for the door.It wasn't an exaggeration to say Lydia Wallace was the it girl of their circle‚Äîbeautiful, talented, fragile in that heartbreaking way that made people want to protect her. Everyone adored her, pitied her, worshipped her.And now that their goddess was hurt?No one had the heart to keep celebrating a proposal everyone already knew the answer to.Even the guy proposing dropped everything and bolted."Jasper‚Äî"The voice that called his name came from behind‚Äîsoft, barely more than a breath.That was when everyone finally realized: the woman being proposed to hadn't said a single word this whole time.Somebody must've hit the lights in the chaos, because the room dimmed. The only glow came from the soft wall lights.In the corner, half in shadow, half in light, stood Claudia Lancaster. Her beauty wasn't the sweet, gentle kind‚Äîit was sharp, striking, unforgettable.But right now, her calm was unnerving. Her expression gave away nothing."You don't want to hear my answer?" she asked quietly.Just a minute ago, Jasper Fenton had asked her to marry him.Now, halfway out the door, he froze.He didn't even try to explain. "Claudia, I'm sorry. I have to go to the hospital. Go home first, okay?""What if I don't let you go?" Her voice stayed steady. "Jasper, you know I hate her."Jasper sighed, exasperated. "Claudia, not now. When I was grieving over my miscarriage, some girl, nine months pregnant claimed that her kid belonged to my loved biker.
"I was looking for Shadow. He has the right to know about the child's existence..." 
Shadow joined the military when he was eighteen, and I had barely seen him since then.
He said no one else had ever been on his bike. I couldn't believe he betrayed me.
"If you continued to make false claims that he would get a DNA test done and then file charges against you." My voice cracked. 
"I haven't lied about anything!" 
I just needed some time. I knew that he would be pissed at me for leaving him. 
But at the time, I thought that it was the right thing to do.
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

Tulip
My name is Tulip Ivy Sterling, and I am 23 years old. My life has been one big trial of ups and downs. And I have to say, there have been more downs than ups. Especially over the last few years. And it has been so hard. Harder than what I had thought that my life would be after I turned eighteen.
Before I turned eighteen, I was used to having a hard life. When I was first born, I had a loving family. I had a mom and two dads, and three brothers. And we were all one big happy family, or so I thought. When I was ten, something happened to cause my parents to split up. I never did find out what happened to cause it.
All I knew was that the boys and I had to go and have DNA tests done to find out which of us belonged to my dad, Sean. Unfortunately for me, I was the only one that the test showed belonged to him. So, I had to spend every weekend at his house with him. And most of my breaks from school were spent at his house. I hated it.
He was always very abusive to me, and it was mentally and emotionally most of the time. When he only had me on the weekends, he would stick to mentally and emotionally abusing me. But when I had to spend a longer amount of time with him, it would get physical. He would beat me and lock me in a closet for hours at a time, sometimes for days.
Once I turned e | When I was grieving over my miscarriage, some girl, nine months pregnant claimed that her kid belonged to my loved biker.

Abandoned as a child, abused in boarding school, and a-ssaulted at thirteen‚Äîat seventeen I was forced to return to my parents‚Äô and brothers‚Äô mansion with my son.
Alex, my brother, stepped forward, his eyes glistening with unshed tears. 
‚ÄúMe and Teo have been looking for you for the past four years,‚Äù he said, his voice thick with emotion. 
His words hit me like a gentle shockÔºåmy brothers had been searching for me all this time.
A faint warmth spread through my chest, chasing away some of the chill of fear. 
But joy turned to agony when they learned my son was three, and realized what had happened to me at thirteen.
Alex‚Äôs fist hit the wall with a crash. Teo just shook his head, face ashen.
Guilt overwhelmed both of them, their shoulders hunched under the weight of it.
 For the first time, someone in this family seemed to grasp the horror I‚Äôd endured.
‚ÄúWe've let you down,‚Äù Teo murmured.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry,‚Äù Alex said, his gaze earnest. 
I whispered, ‚ÄúI believe you.‚Äù
For the first time in years, I felt a glimmer of something like belonging.

Oh sh-it.
I sat frozen in my place. My 17-year-old but, which has seen better, and worse days was numb from not moving for a few hours so I couldn't have been sure whether someone stitched it to the uncomfortable leather seat. It would explain my lack of movement, right?
Wrong.
It was the pair of green eyes, staring down at me, completely shocked. It was my pair of eyes staring down at me in shock.
Funny, the last time I saw the eyes, they were filled with disgust and hatred. I took in his tall figure with masculine appearance in formal clothes, not a suit though, which I have honestly expected when I was told he was coming down here.
I slowly blinked at him, realising I was, in fact, not paralyzed. Good. That was the impulse I needed to clear my throat and stand up awkwardly. He was tall. Too tall. But honestly, due to my up bringing, everyone was taller than me.

Then came the slapping sounds of their bodies colliding. I swayed my hips along with the slapping sounds, imagining a man entering me from behind.

"Kids, your real mother, Lauren, is back. Don't call Rhea 'Mom' anymore. It'll make Lauren sad."
Six years of marriage and that's how my husband chose to humiliate me, standing beside his first love.
I built his empire with him from nothing. I raised the twins Lauren abandoned.
Now that they're healthy and happy, she gets to be the "real" mom again?
So blood beats love, huh?
When he asked for a divorce, I signed without hesitation. Six years was a cheap price to see his true face.
But just as I was leaving, two little voices stopped me, "Rhea, you are our only mom! If you're leaving, we're going with you!"
It was 8:00 pm in Colburn.
Jamison Group's celebration party was in full swing. Laughter echoed across the venue as glasses clinked and compliments flew freely.
At the center of the crowd stood Carter Jamison, the man of the hour. Once from a fallen family, he had clawed his way back up. He had rebuilt the crumbling Jamison Group from the ground up and taken it public again. The achievement was enough to earn endless praise.
"Congratulations, Mr. Jamison. You're truly young and accomplished. I look forward to working with you."
"Mr. Jamison, not only is your career thriving, but your family life seems just as perfect. My wife always says a good partner at home makes all the difference. You're a lucky man."
Of course they were envious. Carter's wife had taken on the role of stepmother at such a young age and raised his two children as if they were her own. What man wouldn't admire that?
As soon as his wife was mentioned, Carter, who had been basking in the spotlight, glanced around the room.
Across the crowd, his wife, Rhea Ravelle, stood poised and elegant in a sleek black evening dress.
She was the one who had planned every detail of that night's party a month in advance. Even in the midst of her busy schedule, she hadn't once neglected the kids.
Now that the children were growing up strong and his career was finally steady, Carter had to admit that none of it wo | "Kids, your real mother, Lauren, is back. Don't call Rhea 'Mom' anymore. It'll make Lauren sad."

Now that they're healthy and happy, she gets to be the "real" mom again?
So blood beats love, huh?
When he asked for a divorce, I signed without hesitation. Six years was a cheap price to see his true face.
But just as I was leaving, two little voices stopped me, "Rhea, you are our only mom! If you're leaving, we're going with you!"

She was the one who had planned every detail of that night's party a month in advance. Even in the midst of her busy schedule, she hadn't once neglected the kids.
Now that the children were growing up strong and his career was finally steady, Carter had to admit that none of it wo | "Kids, your real mother, Lauren, is back. Don't call Rhea 'Mom' anymore. It'll make Lauren sad."
Six years of marriage and that's how my husband chose to humiliate me, standing beside his first love.
I built his empire with him from nothing. I raised the twins Lauren abandoned.
Now that they're healthy and happy, she gets to be the "real" mom again?
So blood beats love, huh?
When he asked for a divorce, I signed without hesitation. Six years was a cheap price to see his true face.
But just as I was leaving, two little voices stopped me, "Rhea, you are our only mom! If you're leaving, we're going with you!"

Jamison Group's celebration party was in full swing. Laughter echoed across the venue as glasses clinked and compliments flew freely.

When I was grieving over my miscarriage, some girl, nine months pregnant claimed that her kid belonged to my loved biker.
"I was looking for Shadow. He has the right to know about the child's existence..." 
Shadow joined the military when he was eighteen, and I had barely seen him since then.
He said no one else had ever been on his bike. I couldn't believe he betrayed me.
"If you continued to make false claims that he would get a DNA test done and then file charges against you." My voice cracked. 
"I haven't lied about anything!" 
I just needed some time. I knew that he would be pissed at me for leaving him. 
But at the time, I thought that it was the right thing to do.
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

Tulip
My name is Tulip Ivy Sterling, and I am 23 years old. My life has been one big trial of ups and downs. And I have to say, there have been more downs than ups. Especially over the last few years. And it has been so hard. Harder than what I had thought that my life would be after I turned eighteen.
Before I turned eighteen, I was used to having a hard life. When I was first born, I had a loving family. I had a mom and two dads, and three brothers. And we were all one big happy family, or so I thought. When I was ten, something happened to cause my parents to split up. I never did find out what happened to cause it.
All I knew was that the boys and I had to go and have DNA tests done to find out which of us belonged to my dad, Sean. Unfortunately for me, I was the only one that the test showed belonged to him. So, I had to spend every weekend at his house with him. And most of my breaks from school were spent at his house. I hated it.
He was always very abusive to me, and it was mentally and emotionally most of the time. When he only had me on the weekends, he would stick to mentally and emotionally abusing me. But when I had to spend a longer amount of time with him, it would get physical. He would beat me and lock me in a closet for hours at a time, sometimes for days.

Chapter 1Bang!The doors to the event room burst open."Something happened to Lydia!" a man shouted as he stumbled in, panic all over his face.The words hit like a bomb.The room‚Äîdecked out in flowers, ribbons, and romantic music, buzzing with excitement over the proposal‚Äîinstantly went still.The man in the spotlight, still down on one knee, ring in hand, spun around in shock."What did you just say?"Quade Zimmer, his blue-dyed hair as loud as his voice, blurted, "Mrs. Lancaster just called‚ÄîLydia's been in a car accident! She's at the hospital right now!"The words had barely left his mouth before chaos erupted‚Äîchairs scraping, heels clacking, people rushing for the door.It wasn't an exaggeration to say Lydia Wallace was the it girl of their circle‚Äîbeautiful, talented, fragile in that heartbreaking way that made people want to protect her. Everyone adored her, pitied her, worshipped her.And now that their goddess was hurt?No one had the heart to keep celebrating a proposal everyone already knew the answer to.Even the guy proposing dropped everything and bolted."Jasper‚Äî"The voice that called his name came from behind‚Äîsoft, barely more than a breath.That was when everyone finally realized: the woman being proposed to hadn't said a single word this whole time.Somebody must've hit the lights in the chaos, because the room dimmed. The only glow came from the soft wall lights.In the corner, half in shadow, half in light, stood Claudia Lancaster. Her beauty wasn't the sweet, gentle kind‚Äîit was sharp, striking, unforgettable.But right now, her calm was unnerving. Her expression gave away nothing."You don't want to hear my answer?" she asked quietly.Just a minute ago, Jasper Fenton had asked her to marry him.Now, halfway out the door, he froze.He didn't even try to explain. "Claudia, I'm sorry. I have to go to the hospital. Go home first, okay?""What if I don't let you go?" Her voice stayed steady. "Jasper, you know I hate her."Jasper sighed, exasperated. "Claudia, not now. "Honey... mmm... I'm tired... no more..."
At three in the morning, I push against the man's lean, moving waist,
only for him to grab my wrist and flip me over, his voice low and rough,
"Shut up and stay down! I'm not finished yet... just bear with it a little longer..."
I clench my eyes shut, swallowing my moans.
This might be the last time I sleep with him‚Äîthis very morning, I secretly visited a law firm and drafted divorce papers behind his back.
Our marriage was a matter of convenience, a business deal, plain and simple.
For me, it was security. For him, it was proof of a legal identity.
Three years married,
he likes having s*x with me, but he doesn't like me.

He'd pull me into dimly lit hallways and steal kisses during family gatherings.
I thought,
maybe someday I could make him love me too.
But when Alessia reappeared in our lives, and his late-night meetings doubled, I lost all hope.
Dominic's rough kisses leave me burning, the fading heat from my last climax already threatening to return.

"Alessia, what's wrong? Don't cry. I'll be right there."
Unspeakable frustration twists inside me.

Dominic doesn't respond.
Helplessness, ache, and the sting of rejection flood my chest‚Äîmixed with something deeper than desire, more like grief‚Ä¶
"Wait‚Äîbefore you go, I just need you to sign a few documents."
I call out hoarsely,
climbing off the bed and pulling the divorce papers from my bag, quickly flipping to the signature page.
"What's this?" Dominic frowns at the documents.
"Just some safety liability forms for a new project I‚Äôm starting with a company," I say, sliding the papers across the glossy wooden table toward him.

until he accidentally discovered a secret hidden in her home,
a child who looked exactly like him.

Prologue
Harper POV

The August sun hits like a spotlight when I step off the bus, and for a second, it‚Äôs hard to tell if the heat prickling under my skin is nerves or excitement. Probably both.

College. A new start. A clean page.

No one here knows who I was in high school ‚Äî the quiet girl with the perfect GPA and the predictable life. Here, I get to decide who I am.

The student tour guide waves a clipboard in the air. ‚ÄúWelcome to Hartwell University! Let‚Äôs get started over by the quad!‚Äù

I adjust the strap of my bag and fall in with the crowd, doing my best to look like I belong. The campus smells like fresh-cut grass and coffee, and everyone‚Äôs talking over each other ‚Äî new roommates, majors, dorms, everything at once.

And then I see him.

Of course I do.

Logan Shaw.

He‚Äôs standing a few rows back, hair still that messy brown that always looks like it should‚Äôve fallen in his eyes but never quite does. Same careless grin. Same stupid confidence.

He‚Äôs got a hockey duffel slung over one shoulder, and even from here I can see how his arms have filled out since high school. He laughs at something a teammate says, loud and easy, like the world‚Äôs already decided to make room for him.

My heart drops, just a little.

Because for a second ‚Äî only a second ‚Äî I‚Äôm back in that hallway at West Ridge High, listening to him brag about skipping prom for ‚Äúplayoffs,‚Äù like feelings were a distraction, like people were just background noise to his goals.

Guess some things don‚Äôt change.

I square my shoulders and look away.

The tour guide points toward the bell tower, saying something about its history since the 1800s. Half the group‚Äôs listening. The other half is either texting or staring at the girl with the clipboard. Typical.

When I glance back again, Logan‚Äôs looking right at me.

Not by accident. Not even pretending it‚Äôs by accident.

His gaze is steady ‚Äî curious, almost like he‚Äôs trying to remember if he‚Äôs supposed to know me. Then he smiles, small and lazy, like he does  | Prologue

Bradley was utterly smitten with Stella. By day, he was an aloof aristocrat; at home, her devoted puppy. But after two years together, she uncovered his secret marriage to his secretary. Desperate, he begged, "Stella, forgive me? You were abroad for three years. I got lonely and saw her as your substitute." Heartbroken, Stella walked away... and wed his brother, Milford. Rumors said Milford was a lifelong germaphobe, yet he spoiled her rotten, even tolerating her cats and dogs. "You're my little house cat already," he teased. "A few more won't hurt." Her cheeks flushed as his playful barbs turned her passionate bites into sweet revenge. At the charity gala, Milford paraded Stella proudly. The once-mighty Bradley lurked in shadows, jealousy boiling, until Milford snarled to his guards, "Toss out that sewer rat."

The only glow came from the soft wall lights.In the corner, half in shadow, half in light, stood Claudia Lancaster. Her beauty wasn't the sweet, gentle kind‚Äîit was sharp, striking, unforgettable.But right now, her calm was unnerving. "Claudia, I'm sorry. I have to go to the hospital. Go home first, okay?""What if I don't let you go?" Her voice stayed steady. "Jasper, you know I hate her."Jasper sighed, exasperated. "Claudia, not now. When that cold-hearted billionaire‚Äîwho stood me up three times at the city hall‚Äîwatched me have a whirlwind marriage with his greatest arch-rival right in front of him, he completely broke down on the spot, collapsing to his knees in tears and snot, desperately begging the woman he once called ‚Äúdispensable‚Äù and ‚Äúreplaceable.‚ÄùAnd I, at last, bloomed with dazzling, unyielding radiance in the arms of the man who always truly understood and cherished my worth. üíî ‚û°Ô∏è üî• üíç
I'd waited eight long hours outside city hall that day, clutching useless queue tickets, my heart splintering with every tick of the clock. Aaron Galloway‚Äîthe man who'd sworn forever‚Äîwas supposed to show for our marriage license. But he ghosted me. Again. For the third time, he'd chosen her: his fragile, "depressed" old flame Patti, the one he could never refuse.
No more tears. No more begging. I pulled out my phone and dialed the number I'd ignored twice before: Fredrick Pollard, Aaron's fiercest business rival, the man who'd proposed every single time Aaron stood me up.
"I agree to marry you," I said, my voice steady for the first time in years.
Fredrick didn't gloat. He simply replied he'd return from his trip in a week‚Äîif I still meant it, we'd meet at city hall. No pressure. No games. Just real choice.
That week, I erased Aaron completely. I boxed every photo, every matching mug, every shared memory in the apartment he'd linked to mine. I called a realtor and listed it for sale‚Äîprice irrelevant; I just wanted every trace of him gone.
Of course, Aaron came home that night with Patti draped on his arm like a damsel in distress. No apology for ditching me. He just announced she was staying because her "depression flared up." Then he ordered me to prep the guest room for her.
I watched him give Patti his bedroom while he slipped into mine hours later, arms wrapping around me like nothing happened. "Sorry I flaked," he murmured against my neck. "Patti needed me. When I was grieving over my miscarriage, some girl, nine months pregnant claimed that her kid belonged to my loved biker.
"I was looking for Shadow. He has the right to know about the child's existence..." 
Shadow joined the military when he was eighteen, and I had barely seen him since then.
He said no one else had ever been on his bike. I couldn't believe he betrayed me.
"If you continued to make false claims that he would get a DNA test done and then file charges against you." My voice cracked. 
"I haven't lied about anything!" 
I just needed some time. I knew that he would be pissed at me for leaving him. 
But at the time, I thought that it was the right thing to do.
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

Tulip
My name is Tulip Ivy Sterling, and I am 23 years old. My life has been one big trial of ups and downs. And I have to say, there have been more downs than ups. Especially over the last few years. And it has been so hard. Harder than what I had thought that my life would be after I turned eighteen.
Before I turned eighteen, I was used to having a hard life. When I was first born, I had a loving family. I had a mom and two dads, and three brothers. And we were all one big happy family, or so I thought. When I was ten, something happened to cause my parents to split up. I never did find out what happened to cause it.
All I knew was that the boys and I had to go and have DNA tests done to find out which of us belonged to my dad, Sean. Unfortunately for me, I was the only one that the test showed belonged to him. So, I had to spend every weekend at his house with him. And most of my breaks from school were spent at his house. I hated it.
He was always very abusive to me, and it was mentally and emotionally most of the time. When he only had me on the weekends, he would stick to mentally and emotionally abusing me. But when I had to spend a longer amount of time with him, it would get physical. He would beat me and lock me in a closet for hours at a time, sometimes for days.
Once I turned e | When I was grieving over my miscarriage, some girl, nine months pregnant claimed that her kid belonged to my loved biker.

Tulip
My name is Tulip Ivy Sterling, and I am 23 years old. My life has been one big trial of ups and downs. And I have to say, there have been more downs than ups. Especially over the last few years. And it has been so hard. Harder than what I had thought that my life would be after I turned eighteen.

After the charity gala, I caught my husband cheating on me with his VP of Marketing.
A low, intimate laugh came from Derek's locked office.
I froze, an earring slipping from my finger. The sound came from his private office, the one even the cleaning staff locked.
I approached, bracing myself for something unknown.
"Charlie doesn't understand me the way you do."
I heard Derek's gentle, intimate voice when I was only three feet from the door.
Then it was her.
Vivian Clarke. 
His VP of Marketing.
Wearing the dress I'd complimented hours earlier‚Äîsitting on his desk, his hand on her waist, intimately.
I didn't gasp. Instead, I stood there for a full three seconds, with a shock-stricken calm, meticulously recording every detail.
The way her fingers were twirling in his hair. The lipstick mark on his collar.The champagne gla-sses on his desk two of them, half-empty, celebratory.
Then I closed the door. Carefully, silently. So quietly that they didn't even notice.
He's a hero in their eyes. A visionary. A godda-mn saint.
And I'm the idiot who believed him.
This perfect life is a lie, and I‚Äôm done playing along.
‚Äî‚Äî
The diamonds feel heavier coming off than they did going on.
I stand in front of the bathroom mirror, fingers working the clasp of the Cartier necklace Derrick gave me for our fifth anniversary. The woman staring back at me looks like she belongs in a magazine spread sleek updo, perfect makeup, designer gown that probably cost more than most people's monthly mortgage. But her eyes are tired. No, not tired. Empty.
I finally get the necklace undone and set it on the marble counter with a soft clink. The sound echoes in the cavernous bathroom, all gleaming fixtures and heated floors. This penthouse has everything. Everything except the one thing I actually need a husband who looks at me like I matter.
Tonight was supposed to be special. The Annual Blackwood Foundation Gala, where Derrick's company donates obscene amounts of money to various charities while everyone  | Abandoned as a child, abused in boarding school, and a-ssaulted at thirteen‚Äîat seventeen I was forced to return to my parents‚Äô and brothers‚Äô mansion with my son.
Alex, my brother, stepped forward, his eyes glistening with unshed tears. 
‚ÄúMe and Teo have been looking for you for the past four years,‚Äù he said, his voice thick with emotion. 
His words hit me like a gentle shockÔºåmy brothers had been searching for me all this time.
A faint warmth spread through my chest, chasing away some of the chill of fear. 
But joy turned to agony when they learned my son was three, and realized what had happened to me at thirteen.
Alex‚Äôs fist hit the wall with a crash. Teo just shook his head, face ashen.
Guilt overwhelmed both of them, their shoulders hunched under the weight of it.
 For the first time, someone in this family seemed to grasp the horror I‚Äôd endured.
‚ÄúWe've let you down,‚Äù Teo murmured.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry,‚Äù Alex said, his gaze earnest. 
I whispered, ‚ÄúI believe you.‚Äù
For the first time in years, I felt a glimmer of something like belonging.

Chapter 1: The Wolfless Omega
Addison 
As I approached the main gates of Blackbolt High, a highschool meant for werewolves, I could already pick up several conversations all around me. It wasn't the first time I had heard most of the chatter, but on that morning, there seemed to be more enthusiasm and I wondered why. Even as I looked around, everyone seemed so hyped.
With my sense of hearing so powerful, it was difficult to focus on a particular conversation.
As soon as I stepped through the front doors, the sound of chatter and lockers slamming was much louder. 
With my head low, I made my way down the crowded hallway so I could get to my locker. I didn't bother to look up as I was certain all I would see would be the mockery on people's faces, just because I was a wolfless Omega, or at least, that was what everyone believed. However, they were absolutely wrong about me.
It had already been two years since I had transferred to Blackbolt High after moving to a small town called Raven Mist, and I was still considered a wolfless Omega.
Just like outside, everyone seemed hyped and I became so curious that I had no choice but to pay attention. I instantly focused on a conversation nearby that caught my attention after two girls ran toward each other behind me.
"This is so cool! A Warrior Selection Competition?" a voice said with excitement.
Curious to see who had just spoken, I discreetly faced the other side and spotted two familiar girls holding some flyers. It was Phoebe and Sally. We weren't friends and I wish we were, but wolfless Omegas got treated like trash at the school. The two of them were Betas.
Shutting that thought out, I decided to listen to their conversation as they leaned against a locker, which wasn't too far from mine.
The flyers in their hands greatly caught my attention.
Phoebe spoke with her hand moving enthusiastically. "I've been training so hard my entire life and I think this competition is my chance to finally prove myself."

Abandoned as a child, abused in boarding school, and a-ssaulted at thirteen‚Äîat seventeen I was forced to return to my parents‚Äô and brothers‚Äô mansion with my son.
Alex, my brother, stepped forward, his eyes glistening with unshed tears. 
‚ÄúMe and Teo have been looking for you for the past four years,‚Äù he said, his voice thick with emotion. 
His words hit me like a gentle shockÔºåmy brothers had been searching for me all this time.
A faint warmth spread through my chest, chasing away some of the chill of fear. 
But joy turned to agony when they learned my son was three, and realized what had happened to me at thirteen.
Alex‚Äôs fist hit the wall with a crash. Teo just shook his head, face ashen.
Guilt overwhelmed both of them, their shoulders hunched under the weight of it.
 For the first time, someone in this family seemed to grasp the horror I‚Äôd endured.
‚ÄúWe've let you down,‚Äù Teo murmured.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry,‚Äù Alex said, his gaze earnest. 
I whispered, ‚ÄúI believe you.‚Äù
For the first time in years, I felt a glimmer of something like belonging.

I sat frozen in my place. My 17-year-old but, which has seen better, and worse days was numb from not moving for a few hours so I couldn't have been sure whether someone stitched it to the uncomfortable leather seat. It would explain my lack of movement, right?
Wrong.
It was the pair of green eyes, staring down at me, completely shocked. It was my pair of eyes staring down at me in shock.
Funny, the last time I saw the eyes, they were filled with disgust and hatred. I took in his tall figure with masculine appearance in formal clothes, not a suit though, which I have honestly expected when I was told he was coming down here.
I slowly blinked at him, realising I was, in fact, not paralyzed. Good. That was the impulse I needed to clear my throat and stand up awkwardly. He was tall. Too tall. But honestly, due to my up bringing, everyone was taller than me.

Everyone thought she was a hillbilly and looked down on her, but after she revealed her true identity, everyone was scared sillyÔºÅÔºÅÔºÅü•µü•µü•µüò±üò±üò±

It was midnight on Boaz Street, Orsin City.

Beep beep beep‚Äî

Sirens screamed as the Royal Special Forces‚Äîelite operators‚Äîsurrounded the auction house, making it impossible to escape.

"All units, lock it down!"

"Fox has been spotted at Waylen Auction House! Her target tonight‚ÄîRothialand's 'Blood Ruby'!"

"She can't get away!"

"Seal every exit! Not a single bug gets out!"

But they were already too late.

Inside, a thick, smoky fog had knocked out everyone‚Äîguards, big shots‚Äîleaving them slumped on the floor.

Among the unconscious crowd, a woman in a sleek black velvet gown walked confidently toward the stage.

She took a gas mask from her bag, sliding it on with practiced ease.

Anyone watching the feed might've thought she was just another rich guest... until she pulled a hairpin from her hair, bent it into a lockpick, and jammed it into the lock of the safe holding the Blood Ruby.

Click. The "unhackable" lock popped open like a cheap toy.

"Sorry, folks," she said with a sly smirk, winking at the security camera. "Thanks for the party, but I'm taking this shiny rock home.

"Night-night."

Right there, with everyone watching, she snatched the Blood Ruby and pocketed it like it was no big deal.

Yup, that was her.

No one knew her past. No one knew who she worked for.

But everyone knew her name‚ÄîFox. The greatest thief in the world, slipping in and out of palaces and vaults like they were nothing.

The only agent ever given a 5S "global threat" classification.

But deep in her mind was another name: Narissa Everton.

"Little Narissa... my sweet flower..." That lullaby from her mother.

Too bad time had blurred the rest. All Narissa could remember was her mother's warm smile‚Äînothing else about where she came from.

With the Blood Ruby in her grip, Narissa was ready to ghost, same as always.

But then‚Äî

Bang!

CH 1: Miscarriage and Infidelity

Piper Rush
‚ÄúMrs. Fox, you lost a lot of blood and had a miscarriage. Sorry, we did all we could,‚Äù the doctor said gently. I cried, screamed, and felt guilty. The loss left my heart torn. I should have been more careful.
Sally, my best friend, stood at my bedside, wiping away tears. She knew how much I wanted this pregnancy.
Just the day before, Sally had rushed me to the hospital. It happened so fast, and I don‚Äôt know the cause of the miscarriage. All I know is that when I woke up, my stomach hurt so much, and I saw thick red fluid flowing and soaking my pajamas. The doctor and several nurses worked hard and tirelessly for hours trying to save my baby, but their efforts were in vain.
I stared blankly at the ceiling, lost in thought.
In the room's corner, the television was showing entertainment news about Kelly White, an internationally renowned actress, returning to Riverside. Her mysterious lover picked her up at the airport. Insiders said Kelly‚Äôs stomach looked strange, like that of a pregnant woman. Of course, it was big news.
I turned my gaze to the screen and recognized the actress‚Äôs beautiful face. She was my cousin. I never imagined she would become famous so quickly.
On the screen, a crowd of people surrounded the beautiful Kelly, who was wearing a pink midi dress. Her sweet smile and sparkling eyes lit up the scene as she held a bouquet of flowers beside her mysterious lover, who covered his face with a mask. He was also wearing a black hat and a black jacket. But I noticed something on his finger.
The ring.
Kelly‚Äôs mysterious boyfriend was wearing the same ring as Martin Fox, my husband. I designed it for our wedding rings, so I couldn‚Äôt have been mistaken. Could someone have copied my design? But something was bothering me at that moment. Something felt off.

After the charity gala, I caught my husband cheating on me with his VP of Marketing.
A low, intimate laugh came from Derek's locked office.
I froze, an earring slipping from my finger. The sound came from his private office, the one even the cleaning staff locked.
I approached, bracing myself for something unknown.
"Charlie doesn't understand me the way you do."
I heard Derek's gentle, intimate voice when I was only three feet from the door.
Then it was her.
Vivian Clarke. 
His VP of Marketing.
Wearing the dress I'd complimented hours earlier‚Äîsitting on his desk, his hand on her waist, intimately.
I didn't gasp. Instead, I stood there for a full three seconds, with a shock-stricken calm, meticulously recording every detail.
The way her fingers were twirling in his hair. The lipstick mark on his collar.The champagne gla-sses on his desk two of them, half-empty, celebratory.
Then I closed the door. Carefully, silently. So quietly that they didn't even notice.
He's a hero in their eyes. A visionary. A godda-mn saint.
And I'm the idiot who believed him.
This perfect life is a lie, and I‚Äôm done playing along.
‚Äî‚Äî
The diamonds feel heavier coming off than they did going on.
I stand in front of the bathroom mirror, fingers working the clasp of the Cartier necklace Derrick gave me for our fifth anniversary. The woman staring back at me looks like she belongs in a magazine spread sleek updo, perfect makeup, designer gown that probably cost more than most people's monthly mortgage. But her eyes are tired. No, not tired. Empty.
I finally get the necklace undone and set it on the marble counter with a soft clink. The sound echoes in the cavernous bathroom, all gleaming fixtures and heated floors. This penthouse has everything. Everything except the one thing I actually need a husband who looks at me like I matter.
Tonight was supposed to be special. The Annual Blackwood Foundation Gala, where Derrick's company donates obscene amounts of money to various charities while everyone  | Abandoned as a child, abused in boarding school, and a-ssaulted at thirteen‚Äîat seventeen I was forced to return to my parents‚Äô and brothers‚Äô mansion with my son.
Alex, my brother, stepped forward, his eyes glistening with unshed tears. 
‚ÄúMe and Teo have been looking for you for the past four years,‚Äù he said, his voice thick with emotion. 
His words hit me like a gentle shockÔºåmy brothers had been searching for me all this time.
A faint warmth spread through my chest, chasing away some of the chill of fear. 
But joy turned to agony when they learned my son was three, and realized what had happened to me at thirteen.
Alex‚Äôs fist hit the wall with a crash. Teo just shook his head, face ashen.
Guilt overwhelmed both of them, their shoulders hunched under the weight of it.
 For the first time, someone in this family seemed to grasp the horror I‚Äôd endured.
‚ÄúWe've let you down,‚Äù Teo murmured.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry,‚Äù Alex said, his gaze earnest. 
I whispered, ‚ÄúI believe you.‚Äù
For the first time in years, I felt a glimmer of something like belonging.
